quote.para: (1) For each State and Territory, what proportion of Australian (a) three year olds and (b) four year olds attend preschool education.
(2) How do these statistics compare with other OECD nations.
(3) What initiatives has the Government taken to: (a) improve basic literacy and numeracy skills in preschool and (b) introduce diagnostic testing for speech and hearing among preschool students.
(4) Does the Government propose to introduce a national preschool program.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (4) The matters raised do not fall within the Family and Community Services portfolio.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Does page 4 of the Australian Taxation Office's June 2000 publication Off-Road Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme Guide for Claimants state that under proposed regulations, like fuels will include heavy fuel oil, light fuel oil and all fuels that attract the same rate of duty as diesel (except for gasoline, coal tar, and coke oven distillates).
(2) Since 1 August 2000 have both diesel and unleaded petrol attracted excise of 38.118 cents per litre.

(3) Given that unleaded fuel is more environmentally friendly than diesel, and is taxed at an identical tax rate, why is the Off-Road Rebate not available for unleaded fuel used for qualifying off-road purposes.
(4) Given the current high cost of diesel, will the Government extend the Off-Road Rebate Scheme to cover unleaded fuel; if not, why not; if so, when will this happen.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The excise rates for both diesel and unleaded petrol were 38.118 cents per litre (cpl) from 1 August 2000 until 31 January 2001 and 39.643 cpl from 1 February 2001 until 1 March 2001. These rates have been 38.143 cpl since 2 March 2001.

(3) The primary purpose of the DFRS is to maintain competitiveness in key export industries by ensuring excise does not act as a cascading cost throughout the production chain. Eligible recipients of the DFRS predominantly use diesel fuel in their activities which is not necessarily the case for consumption of unleaded petrol.
(4) See answer (3)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 6 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many persons in each federal electoral division in Victoria have been awarded the Australian Sports Medal 2000.
(2) What are the names of recipients in the electoral division of Scullin.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised by my department as follows:
(1) and (2) This information is not available on an electorate basis. The breakdown of recipients by state and territory is as follows:
The names of recipients will be published early this year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 6 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) What is the Government's position with regards to bank account fees (a) in general and (b) charged on accounts held by pensioners?
(2) Will the Government legislate to prevent banks from charging fees on bank accounts; if not, why not?
(3) Is he aware that in order to receive their fortnightly Centrelink payments, pensioners are required to have an account with a financial institution and that these commonly attract fees?
(4) Is he aware of any financial institution offering fee-free accounts for pensioners, if so, can he identify these?

(5) Given the Government requires pensioners to have accounts with financial institutions in order to receive government payments, will it legislate to prohibit the charging of fees on these accounts; if not, why not?

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The role of government is not to regulate bank fees and charges, but to ensure that there is sufficient competition, particularly in the area of retail transaction accounts, to keep fees to the minimum necessary. Through the implementation of the Governments response to the 1996 Financial Sector Inquiry (Wallis), the Government is committed to providing an environment for increased competition where consumers in general, including those in receipt of Government pensions, will reap the benefits.

(3) It has been brought to my attention that under section 55(2) of the Social Security (Administration Act) 1999, Centrelink, as the Government Agency responsible for delivering social security payments, is required to pay an individuals income support payments into an account nominated by that person. The Secretary of the Department of Family and Community Services, or his delegate, has discretion under Section 55(4) of the Social Security (Administration Act) 1999, to direct all or part of the recipients payment in a different way than that provided in section 55(2). The term 'nominated account' also includes those provided by Credit Unions and Building Societies.

Although some bank accounts attract fees, many institutions provide accounts that have no fees or which attract fees after a designated number of free transactions have been exceeded. The Government encourages all consumers to take advantage of competition and to shop around for the account that best suits their needs.

(4) The majority of financial institutions offer fee free or low cost bank accounts for pensioners, as well as for other social welfare recipients. A selection of institutions have provided the following information on their low cost accounts and these are provided below.
The information is current as at 22 November, 2000.
Account Name: ANZ Access Simplicity

Account Details: This account includes 6 free self-service withdrawal transactions (ATM's, EFTPOS, Internet and phone banking), with all deposits free of charge and no monthly account service fee. Excess withdrawals are charged as per the ANZ's fee structure. The following access concessions are also available

answer.para: Â· If the account is held at an ANZ country branch where no local ANZ ATM is available, the monthly quota of six free withdrawals includes up to six free branch withdrawals.
Â· For disabled customers unable to use ANZ ATMs, the monthly quota of six free withdrawals includes up to six free branch withdrawals, with excess withdrawals charged at a concessional rate.

quote.para: Account Eligibility: This account is available to all ANZ customers. The ANZ also has Deeming Accounts for pensioners.
Account Name: Basic Account

Account Details: Four free withdrawals per month, with no restrictions as to how these free transactions are used, along with no monthly service fee and no minimum balance. Withdrawals over and above the free limit are charged at a rate applicable to other customers using Westpac's retail banking account (except people with disabilities).
Eligibility: Customers must be in receipt of a Government pension or and the individuals social security payment must go into the account.
Account Name: Numerous accounts

Account Details: The CBA does not charge personal customers monthly account keeping fees nor does it have a minimum balance requirement on accounts. The CBA provides the majority of its aged pension and war veteran customers with a rebate of $6.00 a month, which can be used for a combination of fee-free transactions (eg 2 over the counter withdrawals, or 10 ATM, or 15 EFTPOS). This is an additional rebate, over and above all personal customer relationship rebates. The CBA's Ezybanking account (an alliance with Woolworths) provides for up to 55 free electronic transactions per month (50 in store and 5 additional outside). The bank also provides fee-free banking to people with a disability, who are unable to use electronic banking.
Eligibility: Any customer.
Account Name: Retirement FlexiAccount and Retirement Passbook.

Account Details: The Retirement FlexiAccount provides a monthly rebate of $12.00 for transaction fees, with no account keeping charge. Depending on the customers preference, this account allows the customer to perform up to 10 free ATM, EFTPOS and phone transactions a month, or up to 60 Internet transactions, or alternatively the customer can perform up to 3 free branch withdrawals a month, dependent upon their preference.

The Retirement Passbook account also provides a monthly rebate of $12.00 for transaction fees, with no account keeping charge. This allows the customer to perform up to 3 free branch withdrawals a month, with the monthly rebate allowable increasing by $1.00 for ever $5000 the customers has in the account.
Eligibility: Available to all who have retired.

para.inline: The Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies (AAPBS)

quote.para: The AAPBS has provided the following information on the fee free accounts of selected Building Societies.
Illawarra Mutual Building Society: All pensioner accounts are fee-free (apart from Government fees and charges).
Hume Building Society: The Pensioner Deeming Savings Account is fee-free for aged, veteran affairs pensioners and self-funded retirees (apart from Government fees and charges).
Lifeplan Building Society: The Retirement Maximiser Account is fee-free (apart from Government fees and charges).
The AAPBS has also informed that other building societies offer their members (including those on pensioners) accounts that do not attract fees unless certain transaction limits are reached.

para.inline: Credit Union Services Corporation of Australia Limited (CUSCAL)

quote.para: CUSCAL has informed me that a large number of credit unions offer fee-free accounts for all members (not just pensioners) subject to some conditions. These conditions may include limits on the number of transactions performed (ATMs and EFTPOS), or by total cost up to a monthly allowance, or by the use of a credit unions own branches and ATM's.

(5) No. The Government believes that attempts to legislate to prohibit the charging of fees on bank accounts would be counter productive, by limiting consumer choice and competition. In addition, as the response to question (4) demonstrates, there are accounts available to pensioners that allow them to pay no fees on their accounts.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Building Industry
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2153)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the financial hardship individuals have faced since the Howard Government's failure to introduce a moratorium on GST on building materials and associated costs on building contracts existing prior to 1 July, but not completed before that date.

(2) Were delays in completing the building contracts prior to 1 July a direct result of the introduction of the GST and the rush by individuals to finish or commence building prior to extra charges being incurred after 1 July.

(3) Is the $7000 GST rebate offered to first home buyers, designed to offset the cost of GST, being almost entirely used for the purchase of pre-owned homes that do not attract the GST, thereby negating the intended effect of the rebate.
(4) What is the total sum of revenue obtained by the Government through GST on building contracts that were in existence before 1 July.
(5) Has his attention been drawn to claims of job losses through the slowdown in the building industry; if so, what action will he take to ensure that the building industry does not collapse.

(6) Is the introduction of the GST on existing building contracts prior to 1 July in line with the Government's promise that no-one will be worse off under the GST; if so, why have extra costs as high as $20 000 been incurred by individuals.

(7) What action will he take to ensure that (a) individuals are compensated for losses incurred due to the introduction of the GST in relation to building contracts, (b) a moratorium is put in place to ensure that building contracts can be completed without further penalty, (c) the building industry does not suffer any further losses and job cuts as a result of the introduction of the GST and (d) individuals are compensated for the extra costs incurred in building contracts as a result of the introduction of the GST.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware of building contracts where builders promised completion by 1 July 2000 which were not completed by that date.

(2) Delays in building construction may have resulted from a wide range of factors, including poor weather, the building industry's own publicity regarding the impact of the GST, and some builders taking on more work than they could handle.

(3) I am advised that the States and Territories have indicated that the proportion of first home buyers purchasing new homes is in line with previous experience. Any reports of the effect of the FHOS on first home buyer activity should be treated with caution because of the short duration since the introduction of the FHOS.
(4) This information is not available.

(5) To assist the building industry, the Government has doubled the original $7000 First Home Owners Scheme grant to $14,000 for first home owners who enter into contracts between 9 March 2001 and 31 December 2001 inclusive to build or purchase new but previously unoccupied homes. This measure, together with recent reductions in interest rates, will stimulate the building sector, including many small businesses, which of course will have flow on benefits to other parts of the economy.

(6) Yes it is consistent; income tax cuts more than compensate for these increases when considered in a longer time frame. Further, under the GST transitional arrangements, GST only applies to the value of work done from 1 July 2000 onwards.

(7) The Government has already provided concessional treatment to the construction industry, including construction of residential housing, in the GST transition. The transition rules contain special provisions for construction projects which ensure that they are taxed only on the value of work done after 1 July 2000. In contrast, the general `time of supply' rules in the GST law would tax the full value of the goods supplied to a person from 1 July 2000 at the time those goods are made available to the recipient.

In addition, the GST applies to contracts entered into after the GST legislation became public on 2 December 1998. It is reasonable to expect that people entering into a construction contract after that date would consider the possibility of the actual construction spanning the introduction of the GST. The GST only applies to contracts entered into before 2 December 1998 if the contracts include a provision allowing the price to be reviewed to take account of the GST. Furthermore, builders benefit from the removal of wholesale sales tax from many products used in the construction of houses and other property.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 29 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many recipients of the Australian Sports Medal reside in the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Deakin, (c) Casey, (d) Menzies and (e) Aston.
(2) What are the names of recipients in the electoral division of Chisholm.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised by my department as follows:
(1) and (2) This information is not available on an electorate basis. The breakdown of recipients by state and territory is as follows:
The names of recipients will be published early this year.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission: Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd.
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2230)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) grant a deadline extension to certain parties in relation to the Sydney Airport Corporation Limited Pricing Inquiry as a result of certain ACCC reports being found to be in error; if so, what errors were found.
(2) Are the reports in question those published by the ACCC pursuant to the Airports Act and are based on audited accounts that airports are required by the Act to provide the ACCC.
(3) Has the ACCC been aware of the errors for some time; if so, when did the ACCC first become of the errors.
(4) Having been advised of the errors, did the ACCC publish a correction; if not, why not and who took that decision.
(5) What action has the ACCC taken to ensure that all other reports are correct and that such errors will not occur in the future.
(6) Is he satisfied that the ACCC in publishing incorrect reports and then not correcting them has met it obligations to both the Parliament and the firms that it regulates.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The ACCC advises me that no deadline extensions were granted. They also advise me that minor errors were found in two ACCC reports but that these do not relate to Sydney Airport.

(2) The errors in question relate to two of the 14 annual regulatory reports prepared by the ACCC to date. The regulatory reports cover quality of service monitoring, price cap compliance, prices monitoring and audited airport accounts that the airport operators are required to provide to the ACCC pursuant to the Airports Act.

The errors are minor. They relate to one of the airport account expense line items at one airport, and one of the airport account expense line items and information on airport equity at another airport. In each case the expense totals are correct.

The ACCC advises me that as part of its process for checking the contents of the regulatory reports the ACCC had provided draft reports to all of the airport operators, including the two in question. The airport operators were invited to comment on the draft and check the details. Neither operator reported the errors referred to.
(3) The ACCC advises me that it has been aware of the errors since mid 2000.
(4) The ACCC advises that it will correct the errors as part of the next reporting period. The ACCC is in the process of preparing the reports and will release them early this year.

(5) The ACCC requires accounts to be audited. This is an ongoing requirement. The ACCC also provides draft reports to each of the airport operators to check for errors. The ACCC advises me that it will continue this process. It also advises that this process is supported by the airport operators.

(6) I am satisfied that the ACCC has met its obligations to Parliament and the firms that it regulates. The reports provide unprecedented levels of information on Sydney Airport and the leased airports. The ACCC advises me that airport users, airport operators and airport investors have provided positive feedback on the usefulness of the reports.

subdebateinfo.title: Virgin Blue and Impulse Airlines: Workers Compensation and Superannuation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2277)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: Are both Virgin Blue and Impulse Airlines meeting their legal obligations with respect to workers' compensation payments and superannuation under Commonwealth, State and Territory laws and is such compliance a condition of holding an Air Operators Certificate; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: With regard to any corporate information relating to Virgin Blue and Impulse Airlines, it should be appreciated that both these airlines are private companies. Details of the structuring and administering of their workers' compensation and staff superannuation arrangements, in line with relevant Commonwealth and State law, are therefore matters for the consideration of the airlines' management.

With regard to whether compliance with Commonwealth, State and Territory laws applying to workers' compensation and superannuation arrangements is a condition of holding an Air Operator's Certificate (AOC), the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised that it does not have any legal power to impose conditions on AOCs in relation to workers' compensation and superannuation payments.

Under section 28 of the Civil Aviation Act 1988, CASA is legally obliged, in issuing an AOC, to focus on those matters listed in the section as directly related to the ability of an organisation to conduct or carry out the AOC operations safely. These include the qualifications, licences, and experience of the organisation's personnel, and its facilities, procedures and practices.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Acting Minster for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) In relation to the sale of Sydney Airport, what has been the commercial return on assets for each financial year of the Sydney Airports Corporation Limited (SACL)?
(2) Does the proposed increase in aeronautical charges of 130% include consideration for pre-existing investment?
(3) If the proposed increase in aeronautical charges is approved, what is the expected increase in SACL profits for the next full financial year?

(4) Do current aeronautical charges at Sydney Airport more than allow SACL to recover the costs of its pre-existing investment, if so, is this confirmed by (a) the high rates of return achieved by SACL in 1998-99 and 1999-2000, (b) Standard & Poors A+ long term and A-1 short term credit rating in 1998-99, (c) the Federal Airports Corporation's statements and representations in 1998 that no increase in charges was necessary to achieve a reasonable return on existing investment and (d) current aeronautical charges at Sydney Airport having been set together with those of the Phase 1 privatised airports, which subsequently sold at high earnings multiples?

talk.start.para: âThe Acting Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd has earned the following returns on assets:

(2) SACL's draft proposal values non-land aeronautical assets using the Optimised Depreciated Replacement Cost (ODRC) methodology. This methodology was accepted by the ACCC in its draft decision, released 9 February 2001, as being appropriate.

(3) It is not possible to determine the impact any increase in aeronautical charges will have on SACL's profits next financial year, as SACL's profit reflects a number of factors including, but not limited to, aeronautical revenues.
(4) No. Current aeronautical charges at Sydney Airport are designed to recover 90% of operating costs.
(a) The rates of return earned by Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd were not high for 1998-99 and 1999-00, due largely to the negative return earned on aeronautical assets.
(b) I am not aware of the factors Standard & Poors took into consideration in determining SACL's 1998-99 credit rating.

(c) This issue is the subject of legal action between Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd and a number of its airline customers. Therefore, it is not a matter on which it is appropriate for me to comment.
(d) The current aeronautical charges at Sydney Airport are a legacy of the network pricing of the Federal Airports Corporation. The charges were not set with the Phase 1 privatised airports.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Further to the announcement on 18 January 2001 of Salomon Smith Barney and Freehills to conduct the scoping study into the sale of the Sydney basin airports, what was the composition of the panel that made the selection.
(2) Which individuals or organisations were the independent private sector representatives, referred to in the media statement as being included on the panel.
(3) Who selected the selection panel.
(4) What are the terms of reference for the scoping study and what is its expected cost to complete.
(5) When is the first interim or draft report expected, who will receive that report and when is the final report due.
(6) Will the scoping study be considered by Cabinet.
(7) What are the objectives of the Government for the sale of the Sydney basin airports.

talk.start.para: âThe Acting Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The panel which recommended the selection of Salomon Smith Barney comprised the Chief Executive of the Office of Asset Sales and IT Outsourcing, and two members from the panel of independent private sector representatives. The selection panel for legal advisers comprised the Deputy Chief Executive of OASITO, and two different private sector representatives.

(2) For the investment bank appointment, the private sector representatives were Mr John Dickinson and Mr Peter Nixon AO. For the legal appointment, the representatives were Mr Ron Cotton AM and Mr Murray Campbell.
(3) The independent panellists were approved by the Minister's office and drawn from a list maintained by OASITO of eminent business people who can provide independent private sector expertise.
(4) The terms of reference for the consultancy undertaking the scoping study are attached. The scoping study is expected to cost about $200,000.

(5) Drafts of the report of the scoping study were received by OASITO, who consulted with the Department of Transport and Regional Services and other Departments as appropriate. The final report was delivered in late February.
(6) The Government considered the results of the scoping study and announced its decision on 29 March 2001. A copy of the press release is attached.
(7) The Government's sale objectives are attached to the press release.

para.inline: Sydney Airport Scoping Study Terms of Reference

quote.para: The consultant will be required to undertake the Scoping Study and prepare the report in consultation with the legal adviser, and to provide independent advice, taking into account the Government's decisions on Sydney's future airport needs, and undertake project management activities, in accordance with the following as necessary for the Scoping Study process and/or as requested by OASITO:
(a) Business overview and valuation

answer.para: Â· structure and management issues, with particular reference to the Government's announced intention to privatise the Sydney Airports with Kingsford Smith Airport to be sold separately from the other Sydney Airports and the establishment of conditions to encourage Bankstown to operate as an overflow for Kingsford Smith Airport;
Â· indicative valuation which distinguishes between the valuations attributable to alternative sale methods, timing and sequencing of sales; and
Â· business prospects.

quote.para: (b) The value, feasibility and efficiency of alternative sale options and strategies, taking into account:

answer.para: Â· possible methods for the Sale of the Sydney Airports, including, public flotation, trade sale, or combination such as with a cornerstone investor, recognising the different characteristics of the airports;
Â· likely investors and investor interest;
Â· possible structural alternatives, including sale as a single business or multiple businesses;
Â· timing implications of alternative sale options;
Â· Commonwealth legal and other regulatory issues (ie economic, environmental etc) and cross-ownership restrictions and airline ownership restrictions etc;
Â· industrial relations issues;
Â· the allocation of responsibilities between the Commonwealth and the State of NSW;
Â· aircraft noise regulation;
Â· aircraft traffic distribution - including airspace management considerations;
Â· efficient pricing of services;
Â· proposed changes to the slot management scheme;
Â· Government policy with respect to the future of the Badgery's Creek site; and
Â· Government policy with respect to regional airline services.

quote.para: (c) Action required to prepare SACL for sale, including:

answer.para: Â· market testing;
Â· possible restructuring of Sydney Airport assets to reflect the Government's decisions;
Â· identification of any PR/stakeholder issues which may need to be addressed as part of a Sale;
Â· identifying key issues relative to contracts and operations that may present a risk to the proposed sale process;
Â· determining how to structure the Sale to include commitments to developing:
Â· the businesses of the existing airports;
Â· incentives to encourage infrastructure developments (for instance, the extension of the runway at Bankstown together with the development of a passenger terminal);
Â· ongoing financial and operational management during the Sales process;
Â· any necessary or desirable restructuring of the balance sheet including an appropriate commercial gearing level for the preferred sale method and any restructuring of associated debt; and
Â· advice on future borrowings and capital expenditure program.

quote.para: (d) Any other issues relevant to the Government's consideration of the Sale of Sydney Airports.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is a âlife interestâ in a farm asset valued and assessed for purposes of the Age Pension assets test.

(2) Is it a fact that such life interests are not taken into account if a person was receiving social security support at the time the measure was introduced; if so, will these provisions be extended to people who apply after that date; if not, how does the policy co-exist with the claims made by the Government in its AAA farm package regarding older generational issues.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) A life interest in a farm asset is treated no differently than a life interest in any other asset. Life interests are disregarded for the purposes of the Age Pension assets test unless they are created:

answer.para: â¢ by the person, by the person's partner or both of them; or
â¢ on the death of the person's partner.

quote.para: A life interest in the person's principal home, where the person has reasonable security of tenure, is exempt from the assets test.
(2) The Social Security Act 1991 does not distinguish between life interests created at different times.
The life interest provisions of the Social Security Act 1991 are separate to, and different from, the Agriculture - Advancing Australia (AAA) integrated rural policy package.

The AAA package, through the Retirement Assistance for Farmers Scheme (RAFS), allows eligible older farmers who retire to transfer ownership of the family farm to a younger generation without being subject to the social security deprivation provisions when claiming Age Pension. This is not the same as the life interest provisions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) What are the Government's plans in respect of the proposed sale of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.
(2) Will the proceeds of the sale be used for a specific purpose; if so, what is that purpose.

talk.start.para: âThe Acting Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Following its consideration of the scoping study report into the sale of Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd (SACL), the Federal Government has decided to sell Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport by a 100% trade sale to be completed in the second half of this year.
(2) The proceeds of the sale of Sydney Airport will be applied to reduce Commonwealth debt.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) How many judgements by Justices of the Federal Court of Australia have been outstanding for a period of more than 6 months.
(2) Is he able to say when these judgements will be delivered.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am advised by the Federal Court that as at 27 February 2001 there were only 28 judgments of the Court outstanding for a period of more than six months. The figure of 28 represents only 1.5 per cent of the number of judgments delivered during 1999-2000, that is 1877.
(2) I am further advised by the Court that the judgments will be delivered as soon as possible having regard to the workload of the Court.

subdebateinfo.title: Universities: Information Communications Technology, Mathematics and Science Courses
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2304)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Did he, in his Federation Address `Backing Australia's Ability' on 29 January 2001 announce that over the next five years, each year, an additional 2000 new university places will be created with priority given to Information Communications Technology (ICT), mathematics and science.

(2) Does this mean that in the first year 2000 places will be created, and that in the second year these 2000 places continue, and 2000 new places are created, and that in the third year there are 6000 places, 8000 in the fourth year and 10 000 in the fifth year.

(3) Will these places lapse after three years, so that in the fourth year the first 2000 places disappear, and in the fifth year after three year's tenure, the second tranche of 2000 places are gone, so that in the fifth year there are only 6000 new places.

(4) In either case, does the announcement of 2000 new places each year over the next five years mean more places than the announcement that over that period, this will result in 21 000 equivalent full time student places at a cost of $151 million.

(5) Is his figure of 21 000 places based on an attrition rate expected because these new places will be taken up by students who cannot now gain entrance to university courses, despite the low current entrance criteria for science admissions.

(6) Has the Government rejected the recommendation of the Chief Scientist in The Chance to Change, August 2000, to create 500 HECS scholarships to attract the best students to science degrees, at a total cost for five cohorts of about $40 million, in favour of a program to enrol weaker students at a cost of $151 million.

(7) Does the Government intend to micro-manage the admissions procedures of the autonomous universities to ensure that priority is given to ICT, mathematics and science; if so, does the Government intend to rely on the fact that these new places will be the last choice of aspiring university applicants.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised by my department as follows:
(1) Yes.

(2) (3), (4) Under this initiative, starting from 2002, funding will be provided for 2,000 additional commencing student places. In subsequent years after the first year, funding will also be provided for the places students occupy as they progress through their courses (known as `pipeline').

The formula used to cost proposals for new university places has been in place since 1989 and assumes a standard attrition of 25 per cent between years 1 and 2, 2 and 3, and 3 and 4. Using this assumption, funding will be provided for:
2,000 first year student places in the first year of the initiative;
3,500 places in the second year (2,000 first year student places and 1,500 second year student places);
4,625 places in the third year (2,000 first year student places, 1,500 second year student places and 1,125 third year student places); and
5,469 places in the fourth and subsequent years (2,000 first year student places, 1,500 second year student places, 1,125 third year student places and 844 fourth year student places).
The sum of all commencements with `pipeline' over the first five years of the package is 21,063 equivalent full-time student places.

Commonwealth funding for these places is estimated to be $151 million over the first five years (impact on fiscal balance). Universities will also receive funding for the places through the Higher Education Contribution Scheme.

(5) No. The assumed attrition rate is for the purposes of costing the measure only. The 25 per cent attrition rate has been applied to funding of new student places across all courses (with the exception of medicine) since 1989. Its continued use in costing the present measure assumes no change in this pattern.

(6) Backing Australia's Ability is the Government's strategic response to the key issues identified in a process of wide national consultation and expert review. The Government has had the benefit of both the Chief Scientist's review of Australia's science capability, The Chance to Change, and the report of the Innovation Summit Implementation Group Innovation - Unlocking the Future in developing its statement.

The creation of an additional 2,000 university places per annum over the next five years targeted to priority areas will increase the number of educational opportunities in these areas, and will help to address skills shortages in areas of strategic importance to Australia's emerging technology industries.

(7) No. The new places will be allocated to universities on a competitive basis. Guidelines to assist universities' development of their submissions are being developed by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and will be available shortly.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: Is he able to say what is the probability of an aircraft crashing over populated areas of Sydney.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: A formal risk analysis for Sydney Airport was carried out and extensively discussed in the Environmental Impact Statement for the airport's Third Runway. Amongst the findings, this study reported that the chance of a fatality for an individual in a residential area resulting from an aircraft crash ranged from 40 chances per million per year in the vicinity of the runway alignment close to the airport down to one chance per million per year in the vicinity of the runway alignment in areas about 6 kilometres from the airport. Assessed risks for individuals in areas further from the airport or further from the runway alignment were lower than one chance per million per year. The study compared these risks with a range of everyday risks of fatality for an individual including 110 chances per million per year of being killed in an accident at home.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of best practice in airport environmental management and sustainable airport development.
(2) What constitutes best practice in airport environmental management.
(3) What is the definition environmental capacity for Australian airports.
(4) Can he quantify the environmental capacity of Sydney Airport.
(5) In which year was, or will, the environmental capacity for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA) be reached.
(6) How will environmental capacity influence future KSA development decisions.

(7) Where an airport cannot fully compensate residents in compliance with Australian standards, guidelines or regulations for noise, toxic air emissions, and other relevant Australian quality standards, can it be said to have exceeded its environmental capacity.

(8) In view of Airports Council Internationals recommendations regarding the achievement of long-term sustainable development for airports, can he quantify the maximum level of environmental impacts of Sydney Airport beyond which he will not allow further expansion.

(9) Did Mr Tony Stuart, CEO, in Sydney Airport Corporation Limited's November 1999 Environment Strategy document, state that Sydney Airports mission is to be a world class airport for Sydney, NSW and Australia; if so, does the mission remain unchanged.

(10) Will he give details, prior to approval of privatisation in accordance with the Coalitions Putting People First policy, of the Governments total-airport environmental management strategy for KSA; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Airports Act 1996 establishes a Commonwealth environmental management regime at leased Federal airports. The main elements include environmental strategies for each airport, including Sydney Airport, and the monitoring and remediation of pollution. The regime focuses on a cooperative approach to support and ensure compliance with environment standards at airports.

The Airports (Environment Protection) Regulations set standards and impose duties in relation to environmental pollution (dealing with air, water and soil quality, and noise emissions other than by aircraft in flight); authorise the monitoring and remediation of breaches of environmental standards; and support better environmental outcomes at leased Federal airports.

I would also emphasise that the Environmental Management Systems now being established by the operators of leased Federal airports will be consistent with the International Standards Organisation's (ISO) 14001 Standard for Environmental Management.
(2) The industry generally recognises the ISO 14001 standard as current best practice environmental management.
(3) No definition of âenvironmental capacityâ has been established for Australian airports.
(4) No. See answer to (3).
(5) See answer to (3).

(6) Although âenvironmental capacityâ is not a concept that has been developed in Australia, environmental considerations do have a fundamental role in the decision making process for any future developments at Sydney Airport. Proposals for developing the facilities and operational aspects of Sydney Airport are subject to the assessment and consultation requirements of the Airports Act 1996 and the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.
(7) See answer to (3).

(8) No. The demand for air travel to and from Sydney requires the Government to balance the commercial interests of airport operators and users with the broader interests of the community. Measures to protect the community from the adverse impacts of Sydney Airport include a legislated curfew, the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP), a demand management scheme that limits allocated movements to a maximum of 80 per hour and a noise insulation scheme for public buildings and private residences in the high noise exposure areas.
(9) Yes. The relevant section of the Airport Environment Strategy has not been altered since its approval.
(10) The Airport Environment Strategy for Sydney Airport is a public document. My Office will be happy to make a copy available to the Honourable Member.

subdebateinfo.title: Second Sydney Airport: Environment Assessment Report
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2313)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Did Environment Australia find in its July 1999 Second Sydney Airport Environment Assessment Report (pp.5-4) that the 1985 site selection environmental impact statement ranked Wilton as second overall of the ten sites short listed and the favoured site outside the Sydney basin and that Wilton must rank well as an alternative site to Badgerys Creek; if so, can he provide technical reasons for his exclusion of Wilton and Darkes Forest from consideration as potential new airport sites for Sydney.

(2) Will he recall from schools all copies of the Sydney Airport Corporation Limited's document titled: Sydney Airport Australia's International Gateway teachers and students booklets Human Society and Its Environment Curriculum support materials: Stage 3, on the grounds that it contains biased, misleading and incomplete information.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The July 1999 Environmental Assessment Report by Environment Australia on the Second Sydney Airport proposal did refer to the findings of the 1985 site selection Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) which ranked Wilton as the best of the mid-distance sites while Badgerys Creek was considered to be the best of the closer sites.

The EIS on the second Sydney airport proposal, which was completed in June 1999, was specifically for the Badgerys Creek site. Environment Australia's Guidelines for this EIS clearly acknowledged that alternative site locations would not be addressed in detail having been the subject of a separate `site selection' EIS in 1985 and subsequent Government decisions (except for the Holsworthy site which had been the subject of more recent study).
(2) This is a matter for the Minister for Finance and Administration, the Hon John Fahey MP, who is the portfolio Minister responsible for the Sydney Airports Corporation Limited.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Will he outline the Government's process to be followed concerning the proposed sale of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA).
(2) By what date would the Government prefer KSA to be sold.
(3) Is he aware of the corporate structure of Westralia Airports Corporation Pty Limited.

(4) Is it permissible for those persons who hold an equity interest in (a) Westralia Airports Corporation Pty Limited, (b) Airstralia Development Group, (c) Airport Group International Holdings or (d) any other airport-lessee and airport-management company in Australia to hold equity interest in another airport-lessee or airport-management company in Australia.

(5) Subject to the provisions contained in the Airports Act, is it possible for a person holding an equity interest in an airport-lessee or airport-management company to also hold an equity interest in another airport-lessee or airport-management company.
(6) Is an airport-lessee or airport-management company eligible to sell shares in those companies on the Australian Stock Exchange.

talk.start.para: âThe Acting Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Government has announced that Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport will be sold by way of a 100% trade sale. The press release announcing the sale is attached.
(2) By the second half of 2001.

(4) (5) and (6) The Airports Act 1996 contains provisions relating to the ownership restrictions applicable to airport operator companies, which covers both airport lessee and airport management companies. The Minister for Transport and Regional Services is the responsible Minister.

subdebateinfo.title: Holsworthy Correctional Centre: Inappropriate Disciplinary Action
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2324)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 557 (Hansard, 12 May 1999, page 5321) in which it is stated the only other claims of inappropriate disciplinary action involve another Army unit at Holsworthy, was the unit referred to 3 RAR; if so, what prevented the unit from being named in the answer.
(2) When was the first time that the inappropriate disciplinary action was brought to the attention of the relevant Minister.
(3) Who was that Minister.
(4) Was the Minister or his staff or her staff briefed on the matter by either the ADF or the Department of Defence; if so, on what dates and by whom.
(5) What if any ministerial directions were issued by the Minister, on what date and to what effect.
(6) When was he or his ministerial staff first briefed on the 3 RAR Affair and by whom.
(7) What ministerial directions were issued, when and to what effect.
(8) On what subsequent occasions was he or his staff briefed on the 3 RAR Affair.
(9) What if any ministerial directions were issued, when and to what effect.
(10) Was Minister Moore or his staff briefed on the 3 RAR Affair; if so, when and by whom.
(11) Did Minister Moore or his staff issue or provide any directions; if so when and to what effect.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. Release of detail at the time was inappropriate as it may have prejudiced the investigation or legal proceedings.

(2) While several individual incidents had been reported as representations to the Office of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel commencing in March 1998, formal advice of inappropriate disciplinary action was first received on 22 March 1999.
(3) The Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence.
(4) Yes. The Chief of Army provided a brief on 22 March 1999.
(5) The Chief of Army was asked to ensure all allegations were thoroughly investigated and disciplinary action taken where appropriate.
(6) On 22 March 1999 by the Chief of Army.
(7) The Chief of Army was asked to ensure all allegations were thoroughly investigated and disciplinary action taken where appropriate.
(8) My staff and I have been kept regularly informed on 3 RAR issues.
(9) The Chief of Army was asked to ensure all allegations were thoroughly investigated and disciplinary action taken where appropriate.
(10) The Chief of Army provided a brief to the Office of the Minister for Defence on 22 March 1999.
(11) Yes, that the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence was to handle the issue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 557 (Hansard, 12 May 1999, page 5321) in which it is stated that the military police were investigating claims made against another unit at Holsworthy since September 1998, were the military police given terms of reference; if so, (a) by whom and (b) what were they.
(2) Were the military police investigating individual incidences at 3 RAR; if so, how many.
(3) What were the ranks of the (a) perpetrators and (b) victims.
(4) Were all the available reports and evidence provided to the military police; if so, what was provided; if not, what was withheld and why.
(5) At any point in its inquiry, did the military police form the view that there may have been a culture of violence.
(6) At any stage of its inquiry did the military police put the view to 3 RAR Command that there was a culture of violence in 3 RAR, if so when and to what effect.
(7) Was the military police investigation truncated in any way; if so, how and whose authority.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) and (b) The Chief of Staff, Deployable Joint Force Headquarters, advised Military Police in writing on 14 September 1998 of allegations contained in a statement by a member of 3 RAR. The Chief of Staff provided guidance, which has subsequently been referred to as a Terms of Reference, to Military Police to investigate the allegations. Whilst there was no provision of a formal set of Terms of Reference, guidance for the investigations was made under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.

(2) Allegations contained in the statement by a member of 3 RAR were initially investigated by Military Police as an isolated incident. The Chief of Staff , Deployable Joint Force Headquarters, required any other associated incidents to be investigated. Enquiries into allegations progressively identified information that warranted investigations being conducted with a larger number of personnel resulting in 11 personnel being charged.
(3) (a) and (b) Eleven members and former members of 3 RAR were charged following investigations into allegations made. Of the eleven charges, eight were finalised as at 2 April 2001.

answer.para: Â· A Private tried (incident against another Private) - Found Not Guilty. However, as a result of subsequent Service Police enquiries was charged with a fresh matter (Assault on a Private) and found guilty.
Â· A Private (aid and abet assault on a Private). Not proceeded with due to insufficient evidence.
Â· A Private tried (assault against a Private) - Found Not Guilty.
Â· A Corporal (assault on a Private) - Found Not Guilty (ill-treat inferior), but guilty of (negligent performance of duty).
Â· A Corporal (assault on a Private). Not proceeded with due to insufficient evidence. Complainant did not want matter to proceed.
Â· A Corporal (assault on a Private). Not proceeded with due to insufficient evidence. Complainant did not want matter to proceed.
Â· A Private (assault on a Private) - Found Guilty.
Â· A Private (assault on a Private) was discharged in June 2000 with charge pending. The matter was referred to NSW Police.
Â· A Major (assault on a Lieutenant) - Found Guilty (ill-treat inferior).

quote.para: With regard to the remaining two matters, legal proceedings are continuing and it would be inappropriate to provide details until proceedings have been completed.

(4) No. Military Police Investigators provided a notification of requirement to provide documentation to the Commanding Officer 3 RAR. Documents requested were sourced and provided to the Military Police. Duty Officer Logs prior to January 1997, Battalion Orderly Sergeant Logs from January 1996 to October 1997 and Guard Commander Reports from January 1996 to October 1997, March 1998 to May 1998, April 1999, July 1999 and October 1999 could not be located. Certification that documents could not be located was advised to the Military Police in writing.
(5) No. The preamble to the final report submitted by the Military Police refers to an alleged culture of violence. The report does not state a culture of violence existed.

(6) Current and former members of 3 RAR's chain of command were questioned as part of the Military Police investigation concluded on 29 April 1999. When current disciplinary proceedings are concluded the degree of command responsibility for the incidents as a whole will be determined.

(7) No. The Military Police investigation had been ongoing for seven months by March 1999. Investigators were asked on several occasions prior to March 1999 what support or other action was required to ensure the investigation was conducted thoroughly and quickly. There was no direction by any person to the Military Police to truncate the investigation.

subdebateinfo.title: UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2333)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 6 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Did Australia on 30 October 1989 accept the UNESCO 1970 Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property.
(2) Has he noted the recommendations of the Illicit Trade Advisory Panel in a report to the British Arts Minister on 18 December 2000 that the UK should accede to the Convention.
(3) What progress has been made since the answer to question No. 1674 (Hansard, 31 August 2000, Page 19963) in returning Indigenous human remains from the UK to Australian Indigenous communities.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe following information is provided in response to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) âThe 1970 UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibition and Prevention of Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property was accepted by Australia on the 30 October 1989, with entry into force in Australia 30 January 1990.â
(2) âThe recommendations of the Illicit Trade Advisory Panel put to the British Arts Minister in a report on 18 December 2000, that the UK should accede to the Convention, has been noted.

In relation to that recommendation put to the British Arts Minister by the Illicit Trade Advisory Panel, the Australian Government does not advise the British Government about its decisions concerning international conventions.â

(3) âIn June 2000 my predecessor, Senator Herron, made a submission on this issue to the House of Commons Culture, Media and Sports Committee inquiry into Cultural Property: Return and Illicit Trade. The Australian and British Prime Ministers issued a joint statement on 4 July 2000 that outlined their governments' commitment to increasing efforts to repatriate human remains to Australian Indigenous communities.

In this context, and as already mentioned in question No. 1674 (Hansard, 31 August 2000, Page 19963), there are legislative constraints on certain items such as human remains. Consultations are currently being undertaken by the British Government within its own dominion on the terms of legislation to permit the trustees of the national museums to remove human remains from their collections, allowing facilitation and repatriation of Australia's Indigenous human remains.
I am unable to comment about the likely timing of any future British Government legislation regarding this matter.â

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Was the Rome Statue of the International Criminal Court adopted in Rome on 17 July 1998.
(2) Was the Statute signed for Australia, subject to ratification, on 9 December 1998.
(3) Which other states have (a) signed and (b) ratified the Statute, and on what dates did they do so.
(4) Is his Department the lead agency in developing the legislation to implement the Statute.
(5) What is the timetable for the introduction of the legislation.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) As at 30 April 2001, 139 States had signed and 30 States had ratified the Statute. Information as to those that have signed and ratified is attached.
(4) Yes.

(5) Drafting instructions have been issued for the legislation and drafting is now proceeding. It is hoped that drafting will be completed and the legislation introduced as soon as practicable. The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties is also conducting an inquiry into the Statute, and will be examining the legislation in the context of that inquiry.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 February 2001:

quote.para: How many Defence Reserve training depots were in use in each State or Territory as at (a) March 1996, (b) October 1998 and (c) February 2001.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: There has been about a 25 per cent decrease in the number of reserve depots over the last four years. The location of many depots is based on historical and demographic factors. Some depots are no longer viable and the facilities are outdated. While a number of properties have become surplus, new multi-user depots are being constructed in a number of locations to provide better, more functional facilities with a focus on collective training and improved readiness levels for Reserves.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) What amount of GST Start-Up Assistance money was paid to the Tourism Council of Australia (TCA).
(2) On what dates were the grants paid to the TCA.
(3) What amount of the grant funding paid to the TCA remains unspent.
(4) What due diligence did Treasury undertake to determine the TCA's solvency before the payment of the grant.
(5) How does his Department intend to recoup the unspent grant funds.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The amount paid under the contract was $2,316,850.
(2) Five payments, totalling the full amount of the contract, were made to the TCA on the following dates: 5 November 1999, 5 January 2000, 1 March 2000, 19 April 2000 and 30 June 2000.
The first payment was made after signature of the contract and each subsequent payment was made on the basis of an activity report from TCA in respect to delivery against the contract.

(4) Organisations were selected under the Organisation Delivered Assistance programme on the basis of a risk management assessment of the capacity of the organisation to deliver services under the contract.

This involved an assessment of the proposals against a set of criteria to ascertain the ability of the organisation to deliver the programme. This was developed to meet the requirements of Treasury's Chief Executive Instructions under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 and relevant risk management standards.
Treasury also undertook an ASIC check to ascertain the status of the entity as a registered company.

Treasury's contracts under this programme were structured to minimise the Commonwealth's risk. This involved an initial payment, with most funding paid as instalments after an acquittal of previous payments against the delivery of milestones. Other risk controls included a requirement that funding could only be used the carry out the project, could not be used to meet past deficits or expenditures and were subject to an independent audit.

In relation to TCA, there has been no failure in the risk management procedures as an independent audit of the contract confirms that the public funding provided under the contract has been acquitted to meet its contractual obligations.
(5) The Department is dealing with the Voluntary Administrator on this matter.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) What is the current Family Court of Australia fee for (a) Application for divorce (Form 4), (b) Application for nullity (Form 2), (c) Application for declaration of validity (Form 6), (d) Application for final orders Form (3), (e) Response to application for final orders (Form 3A), (f) Notice of appeal to Full Court (Form 42), (g) Notice of appeal from court of summary jurisdiction (Form 43) and (h) Fixing of hearing date (defended matters).
(2) When were these Family Court of Australia fees most recently increased.
(3) What was the percentage increase for each fee on each occasion.
(4) What was each fee prior to its most recent increase.
(5) When are Family Court fees next scheduled to be increased.
(6) Is it the case that Family Court fees are regularly increased by changes in the CPI.
(7) Will the next increase of Family Court fees use CPI figures which include the impact of the inflationary spike caused by the introduction of the GST.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The current Family Court fees are:
(a) Application for divorce (Form 4) $526
(b) Application for nullity (Form 2) $526
(c) Application for declaration of validity (Form 6) $526
(d) Application for final orders (Form 3) $158
(e) Response to application for final orders (Form 3A) $158
(f) Notice of appeal to Full Court (Form 42) $648
(g) Notice of appeal from court of summary jurisdiction (Form 43) $648
(h) Fixing of hearing date (defended matters) $315
(2) The last increase in Family Court fees was on 1 July 2000. This was the first increase in fees for two years.
(3) The fees were increased by 4.07% according to a formula involving the All Groups Consumer Price Index.
(4) The fees prior to the most recent increase were:
(a) Application for divorce (Form 4) $505
(b) Application for nullity (Form 2) $505
(c) Application for declaration of validity (Form 6) $505
(d) Application for final orders (Form 3) $152
(e) Response to application for final orders (Form 3A) $152
(f) Notice of appeal to Full Court (Form 42) $623
(g) Notice of appeal from court of summary jurisdiction (Form 43) $623
(h) Fixing of hearing date (defended matters) $303
(5) Regulations 21AA and 21AB of the Family Law Regulations 1984 provide for the biennial increase of fees payable in the Family Court. The next increase will take effect on 1 July 2002.
(6) The Family Law Regulations provide for biennial fee increases according to a formula involving the All Groups Consumer Price Index.

(7) Regulation 21AB provides the formula for calculating the increase. The formula for the next increase, for July 2002, will involve using the All Groups Consumer Price Index numbers for the 2000 and 2002 March quarters.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a recent international study of 750 websites conducted by Consumers International which found that (a) few web sites gave meaningful information about how information collected from consumers would be used, (b) some companies used information to selectively raise prices for some customers and (c) only 10% of 102 children's sites asked children to obtain parental consent before disclosing material online.

(2) What measures are currently in place to ensure that businesses which collect personal information from consumers via the internet (a) provide information about how information collected from consumers will be used, (b) do not use such information to selectively exploit customers and (c) obtain parental consent before collecting personal information from children.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware of the Privacy@net comparative study of consumer privacy on the Internet produced by Consumers International in January 2001 on the basis of assessments carried out between March to July 2000. I understand that a main objective of the study was to compare the experience of consumers in the United States (US) and the European Union (EU) because of the differences in approach to regulation between the two. Of the 751 sites assessed for the study 679 were in either the US or the EU. The Australian Consumers Association participated in the study, contributing 29 questionnaires, presumably about Australian sites.

(2) As the honourable member is aware, the Parliament passed the Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Act 2000 in December last year to set privacy standards for the handling of personal information by private sector organisations. That Act, which contains amendments to the Commonwealth Privacy Act 1988, will come into effect on 21 December this year. Most organisations covered by the legislation have the time up to that date to review their current practices and procedures to ensure compliance with the National Privacy Principles. The legislation is technology-neutral and will apply equally to the digital and paper-based environments.

As a result of self-regulatory initiatives in recent years, many organisations would be presently complying with the Privacy Commissioner's National Principles for the Fair Handling of Personal Information pending the commencement of the legislation. The National Privacy Principles in the legislation are based on the Privacy Commissioner's National Principles. Among other things these Principles encourage businesses to inform consumers about the purposes for which their personal information is being collected, and how the business intends to use and disclose that information.

The Office of the Federal Privacy Commissioner is taking an active role to assist organisations prepare for their new statutory privacy obligations. Relevant information can be accessed through the Commissioner's web site [www.privacy.gov.au].

The Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Act 2000 does not contain specific provisions about the need to obtain parental consent before collecting personal information from children. Following my announcement in December 2000, my Department is convening a Consultative Group and is preparing a discussion paper for broader consultation on the issue of children's privacy.

In May 2000 the Hon Joe Hockey MP, Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, released a best practice guide for businesses and consumers in relation to e-commerce dealings. Among other things, Building Consumer Sovereignty in Electronic Commerce: A best practice model for business, contained guidance on fair business practices, privacy issues and advertising or marketing to children under 16 years.

The Australian Broadcasting Authority's Children's Television Standard contains standards concerning advertising to children. The Australian Broadcasting Authority web site, Australian Families Guide to the Internet, launched in November 1998, provides parents and carers with useful information and tools to guide their children to get the best out of the Internet, while protecting them from the worst. While Governments can legislate to put measures in place to assist in protecting children from the risks of using the Internet, parents and carers will always be in the best position to monitor how their children use the Internet.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article entitled âHow canny ones can abuse systemâ in the Australian Financial Review on 31 January 2001.

(2) Given the three year rolling average that is used to determine the level of research and development (R&D) spending, how will the Government prevent companies from lowering their expenditure on R&D this year to qualify for a higher proportion of future expenditure.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) Anti-avoidance measures will be introduced as part of the concession to prevent any potential abuse.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware of new evidence unearthed by the non-government Documentary Centre of Cambodia of the notorious Tuol Sleng interrogation and detention centre in central Phnom Penh regarding the presence of Chinese advisers to the Pol Pot regime.

(2) Has the Australian Embassy in Phnom Penh or the Australian Chinese Human Rights Dialogue evaluated the photographs and evidence that 10 Chinese advisers provided training to the Pol Pot death squad.

(3) Is he able to say whether a Chinese Embassy spokesperson Wu Chingshen warned the editors of the capital's English language daily newspaper the Phnom Penh Post of unspeakable negative effects if they published the story.
(4) Did the Beijing regime in November oppose the proposal of the UN special envoy on human rights to Cambodia to elect a permanent or even ad hoc international tribunal on Khmer Rouge genocide.
(5) Has the Chinese Government taken over much of the suspended Western aid to the Hun Sen Government in Cambodia.
(6) Has the Hun Sen Government thwarted recent proposals for an international criminal tribunal into the crimes of the Khmer Rouge.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) Embassy officials have met with Youk Chhang, Director of the DCC in regard to this story and the report prepared by the DCC.

(4) Chinese Government opposition to the United Nations Special Envoy on Human Rights, Thomas Hammerberg's submission to the United Nations General Assembly in November 1997, calling for the United Nations to proceed with an international Khmer Rouge Tribunal, has been well documented.
(5) The Chinese Government is a significant player in Cambodia. It is not possible to quantify China's financial aid to Cambodia as these figures are not released by the Chinese Government.

(6) The Australian Government has welcomed the conclusion of deliberations on the draft Khmer Rouge Law by the Cambodian Constitutional Council on 12 February. This follows the successful passage of the law through the Cambodian Parliament and Senate in January. The draft law will now be re-considered by the National Assembly and then submitted to King Norodom Sihanouk, before final consultations between the Cambodian Government and the United Nations. These are positive developments for Cambodia in moving a step closer to bringing to trial senior Khmer Rouge leaders, an issue in which great sensitivities still exist within Cambodian society.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2145, how many medical reports from senior specialists addressing the medical condition of former Senator Malcolm Arthur Colston were submitted to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) on 7 April 1999 by the solicitors acting for Dr Colston and when were the reports dated.

(2) Following the request by the DPP that Dr Colston be independently examined to assist the Acting Director to assess the submission made on behalf of Dr Colston by his solicitors, can the DPP confirm that on 3 May 1999 Dr Colston's counsel stated in the Supreme Court that Dr Colston had agreed to be so medically examined.
(3) Can the DPP confirm that, after 3 May 1999, Dr Colston was separately examined by two eminent medical specialists.
(4) What was the process employed by the DPP to select the independent medical specialists to examine Dr Colston.

(5) Did an officer of the office of the DPP recommend to the DPP the names of one or both of the eminent specialists to medically examine Dr Colston; if so, what are the qualifications of the officer who made the recommendation to the DPP.
(6) What are the disciplines of the two eminent specialists selected to examine Dr Colston and what medical qualifications does each specialist possess.
(7) On what dates did the examinations of Dr Colston by the two eminent specialists take place.
(8) Is he able to say how Dr Colston was examined, including the nature of the examinations and what was involved in each examination.
(9) Were written reports of the examinations provided to the DPP.
(10) What are the dates of the reports.
(11) Does either report express an opinion on the life expectancy of Dr Colston; if so, is any opinion expressed in weeks, months or years.
(12) What fees were charged by each specialist for their medical reports.

(13) Apart from the medical report dated 23 November 2000 provided to the DPP by Dr Colston's solicitors, were any other medical reports on the state of health of Dr Colston provided or obtained by the DPP after the DPP's media statement of 5 July 1999 not to proceed with the prosecution of Dr Colston; if so, (a) how many reports were provided; (b) what are the dates of the reports and (c) what are the medical qualifications of each author of the reports; if other reports were not obtained, why not.
(14) Does the medical report of 23 November 2000 provided to the DPP by Dr Colston's solicitors indicate any improvement in the state of health of Dr Colston.
(15) Does the medical report of 23 November 2000 provided to the DPP by Dr Colston's solicitors indicate any deterioration of the state of health of Dr Colston.
(16) Were any reports obtained by the DPP after 5 July 1999 not provided through Dr Colston's solicitors; if so, (a) how many and (b) what are the dates of the reports.

(17) Is the DPP aware of media reports on 14 November 2000 that Dr Colston had been admitted to Wesley Private Hospital in Brisbane just days after the office of the DPP announced it was reviewing its decision to drop travel rorts charges against him.
(18) Is the DPP aware of media reports on 14 November 2000 that sources had revealed that tests had shown cancer had spread to all of Dr Colston's vital organs.

(19) Has the DPP obtained a copy of any of the medical tests conducted on Dr Colston arising from his admission to Wesley Private Hospital in Brisbane; if not, why not; if so, do the results of those tests indicate a deterioration of Dr Colston's health.
(20) On what date did the DPP re-open its investigation of Dr Colston's case.
(21) What was the basis for re-opening the investigation of Dr Colston's case.
(22) Is Dr Colston now capable of standing trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) The DPP selected leaders in their respective fields relevant to Dr Colston's condition.
(5) Yes. Legal.

(6) (i); Medicine; Professor of Medicine, Dr of Medicine, Fellow of Royal Australian College of Physicians. (ii) Surgery; Professor of Surgery, Dr of Medicine, Fellow of Royal College of Surgery, Fellow American College of Surgeons.
(8) Dr Colston was physically examined.
(9) Yes.
(11) Yes. Months.
(19) No, as the independent experts retained by the DPP have assessed medical tests conducted on Dr Colston. Yes.
(21) The need to ascertain Dr Colston's current medical condition.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report of a cocktail party at the Australian Embassy in Beijing involving the Member for Farrer during which the Member for Farrer announced Australia's support for the 2008 Olympics being hosted in Beijing.
(2) Do the Member for Farrer's views officially represent the attitude of the Australian Government.
(3) Has the Government previously announced its attitude to Beijing hosting the 2008 Olympics.

(4) Does such an announcement pre-empt the decision and rights of the Australian International Olympic Committee (IOC) delegation to the 2001 Moscow IOC meeting where a decision about the 2008 Olympics will be made.
(5) Will his Department's China-Australia Human Rights Dialogue be consulted about the Government's attitude towards Beijing hosting the 2008 Olympics.
(6) If the Australian representatives of the Dialogue have been consulted about the suitability of Beijing as a site for the 2008 Olympics, what was their recommendation.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) No. The Member for Farrer visited Beijing as a private individual in the context of consultancy work which the ACT Government is conducting with its sister city Beijing in relation to environmental aspects of Beijing's bid for the 2008 Olympics, and as the former Mayor of the Paralympics Games Village in Sydney in 2000.
(4) Not applicable.
