(5) and (6) Beijing's bid for the 2008 Olympics was not discussed at the last meeting of the bilateral Australia-China Human Rights Dialogue in August 2000. The next meeting will likely be held in August 2001 and no agenda has yet been set.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 27 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Will the Government's new Postgraduate Loan Education Scheme be made available to Australia's two private universities, Notre Dame University in Fremantle and Bond University on the Gold Coast.
(2) What reasons can he give for the policy decision in referred to in part (1).

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Postgraduate Education Loans Scheme will be available to Notre Dame University but will not be available to Bond University.

(2) The Government has made the Postgraduate Education Loans Scheme available to students who are enrolled at universities which receive Commonwealth operating grant funding under the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 and have access to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the British Government intends to proscribe the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) under the Anti-Terrorism Act 2000.
(2) Is he able to define the criteria upon which an organisation under this Act is so proscribed.
(3) Is he able to identify the rights upon which an organisation so proscribed may appeal such a decision; if so (a) what are those rights and (b) what is the procedure to be taken.
(4) Is he able to identify the grounds upon which the LTTE have been nominated under the Act to be a proscribed organisation.
(5) What is the Australian Government's declared position in relation to the LTTE.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. The Home Secretary, Jack Straw, provided a parliamentary answer on 28 February which laid a draft order under section 123 (4) of the Terrorism Act 2000 recommending to Parliament that the LTTE and 20 other organisations be added to the list of proscribed organisations in schedule 2 of the Terrorism Act. The draft order is subject to the affirmative resolution procedure of the British Parliament. There will therefore be debate in both houses on the Home Secretary's recommendations. If approved by Parliament, the proscriptions will take effect on the day the Home Secretary signs the order. Proscription will make it illegal for proscribed organisations to meet, operate or carry out any activities in the UK.

(2) Yes. Under section 3 (3) (A) of the Act, the Home Secretary may by order add an organisation to schedule 2 where he believes that it is concerned with terrorism as defined in section 1 of the Act.

(3) Yes. Proscribed groups have a right of appeal. Firstly, they may appeal to the Home Secretary for de-proscription. Secondly, if that application is refused, they may appeal to the âProscribed Organisations Appeal Commissionâ. This Commission has a special mandate to hear sensitive classified material. Such material will be protected by provisions which allow the advocates of the proscribed organisation to have access to it, but not the organisation or its members.

(4) Yes. The following is the publicly available text which UK parliamentarians have available to assist their consideration of the draft order to proscribe the LTTE. As such, it constitutes the grounds upon which the LTTE have been nominated under the Act to be a proscribed organisation.
â Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE)
Aims: The LTTE is a terrorist group fighting for a separate Tamil state in the north and east of Sri Lanka.
History: The LTTE has been fighting since 1983. More than 60,000 people on all sides have been killed in the conflict.

Attacks: The LTTE have mounted both a military assault and a terrorist campaign, the latter mainly in Colombo. Attacks are mostly targeted against Sri Lankan military and leading politicians using suicide bombers. Attempts to assassinate the Sri Lankan President in late 1999 and early 2000 were attributed to the LTTE by the media and the Sri Lankan authorities.

Attacks on UK or Western interests: The LTTE has never targeted Western interests directly, though Westerners have been injured as a result of LTTE attacks in Sri Lanka. The LTTE's only attack outside Sri Lanka was the assassination of Rajiv Gandhi in 1991 in response to India's military support for Sri Lanka.
Representations/Activities in the UK: The LTTE's international secretariat is based in the UK and is responsible for the group's press releases. The UK is also a source of funds for the LTTE.â

(5) The Australian Government condemns and abhors the terrorist activities of the LTTE. The suicide bombing campaigns that the LTTE have launched, principally in Colombo, have not only aimed at assassinating Sri Lankan political and military figures, but also have been intended to cause the maximum amount of terror amongst the civilian population. While foreigners have not been the direct targets of LTTE attacks, on a number of occasions Australian citizens, including the staff of our High Commission in Colombo, have had narrow escapes from LTTE bombing attacks which have tended to be targeted at crowded public places. The LTTE gives no warning of its attacks and its explosive devices are designed to maximise death and injury.
In 1996 I said in Parliament that I would not meet with Tamil groups unless they first renounced the LTTE's use of terror in writing.

subdebateinfo.title: Prime Minister and Cabinet Portfolio: Procurement Policies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2383)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised by my department as follows:
For all agencies within the Portfolio
(2) The Department closely follows Commonwealth Government Procurement Guidelines in the purchasing of all goods and services.

(3) (a) to (f) No weighting to the core principles is applied when assessing procurement opportunities. For each purchasing activity, departmental officers are encouraged to use their judgement in ensuring all of the procurement core principles of the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines are adhered to.

(4) For each purchasing decision, the Department considers each of the core procurement principles, including the requirement to ensure Australian and New Zealand suppliers have fair opportunity to compete for departmental business.

(5) No. However in each procurement decision the department remains conscious of the principle relating to open and fair competition and government policy supporting the development of competitive Australian and New Zealand Industries.

(6) The attention of all staff involved in procurement activity is drawn to the departmental Chief Executive Instructions, which provide detailed guidance in relation to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Department of the Treasury (Treasury) purchased approximately 7,160 reams of paper during the financial year 1999-2000.
(2) Treasury applies the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(3) Treasury applies a rating scale specific to the tender request. The criteria developed for each tender process are underpinned by these six core procurement principles and weighted accordingly.
(4) Treasury Procurement guidelines require Departmental Procurement Officers investigate ANZ industry capability and provide fair opportunity for ANZ suppliers to compete.
(5) Tenderer's for supply of goods are not advised they must offer ANZ goods. However, fair opportunity is provided for ANZ suppliers to compete as outlined in 4 above.
(6) Treasury applies weighting to tender evaluation criteria as outlined in 3 above.
(1) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) uses approximately 40,000 reams of office paper per annum.

(2) ABS Chief Executive Instructions make reference to the Guidelines. The ABS actively trains its procurement staff and has undertaken internal audits and reviews of the purchasing function, to ensure that purchasing activities are consistent with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

(3) ABS does not weight the core principles, which underpin the procurement guidelines, but does use weighting systems that ultimately achieve outcomes consistent with the principles. However, the primary objective of the ABS is achieving value for money in a manner consistent with the other core principles of the Guidelines.

(4) The ABS encourages competition from ANZ suppliers through active local advertising, market research, and by preparing specifications which are not discriminatory, consistent with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(5) The ABS does not specify that suppliers must offer ANZ goods, as this would be inconsistent with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(6) See response to (2).
(1) The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (the Commission) uses approximately 11,600 reams of paper per annum.
(2) The Commission follows the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(3) The Commission applies equal weighting for (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition (c) fair dealing and (d) accountability.
(4) The Commission does not weight ANZ suppliers, but supply of ANZ goods is encouraged.
(5) The Commission does not advise tenderer's they must offer ANZ goods but they are encouraged to do so.
(6) The Commission applies weighting in accordance with (3) above.
(1) Australian Prudential Regulatory Authority (APRA) uses approximately 4,320 reams of paper per annum.
(2) APRA procurement methods are consistent with Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines as Government contracts for suppliers are used when possible.
(3) In most cases value for money is the highest weighted criteria.
(4) APRA provides fair opportunity to all suppliers.
(5) No, however refer to question 4.
(6) Refer to question 3.
(1) The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) uses approximately 96,000 reams of paper per annum.

(2) All significant purchases, including office supplies, are subject to a tender process where core principles are adopted; otherwise for minor procurement, the principles that underpin the procurement guidelines are generally adhered to.
(3) In most instances all these principles underpin the agency's procurement decisions. However, no single methodology or weighting criteria is used to determine importance.
(4) No weighting criteria are used however all significant procurement specifications and evaluation criteria are drafted to ensure ANZ suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) Yes.
(6) ASIC applies weighting to tender evaluation criteria as outlined in 3 above.
(1) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has purchased 206,644 reams of Australian paper in the financial year up to the date of this question.

(2) The ATO has established Accredited Procurement Units (APU) to ensure that the Commonwealth procurement guidelines and the ATO's procurement policies and procedures are adhered to. The ATO's Chief Executive Instructions also support and reinforce the Commonwealth procurement guidelines.

(3) The ATO's process requires approval by both the Financial Management Act (FMA) delegate and the APU. An officer from the APU units reviews all documentation and approves the procurement process to ensure that, amongst other requirements, the Commonwealth and ATO procurement guidelines, policies and processes are followed including the principles detailed.
The principles outlined are in the main included in the criteria against which proposals are assessed.
(4) The ATO ensures that ANZ suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete

answer.para: Â· In the tender documents ATO makes clear reference to expectations of suppliers in the use of ANZ products and services, and
Â· In their response tenderers are required to declare acceptance of the Commonwealth Government's requirements.

quote.para: (5) The ATO's tender documentation states the Commonwealth Government's requirements in relation to ANZ products and services. Tenderers are required to state that they are prepared to accept the Commonwealth Government's requirements.
(6) The ATO's policy and procedures comply with the Commonwealth Government's procurement policy.
(1) The National Competition Council (Council) uses approximately 600 reams of paper per annum.

(2) All significant purchases, including office supplies, are subject to a tender process where core principles are adopted; otherwise for minor procurement, the principles that underpin the procurement guidelines are generally adhered to.
(3) Council rates value for money higher than the other core principles. A variable rating scale is applied the remaining core principles depending on the good or service required.
(4) Council implements the procurement guidelines.
(5) Council does not advise tenderer's they must offer ANZ goods but they are encouraged to do so.
(6) Council applies ratings as outlined in (3) above.
(1) The Productivity Commission (PC) uses approximately 6,400 reams of paper per annum.

(2) PC has particular regard to section 44 of the FMA Act that agency chief executives promote an efficient, effective and ethical use of Commonwealth resources. This requirement generally aligns with criterion (a) of the Commonwealth procurement guidelines that purchasing decisions reflect `value for money'. In practice, this means evaluating quotes from a number of suppliers taking into account the best value for money criterion to ensure the best available outcome for the Commission.
(3) PC applies the greatest weight to the value for money criterion, with consideration to other criteria as appropriate.
(4) PC's procurement approach provides an opportunity for ANZ suppliers to quote.
(5) Suppliers are advised that ANZ goods must be offered.
(6) Not applicable.
(1) The Royal Australian Mint (RAM) used approximately 1596 reams during 1999-2000.
(2) RAM follows Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

(3) RAM does not weight the core principles but does use weighting systems that achieve outcomes consistent with the principles. The primary focus is to achieve value for money consistent with the other core principles.
(4) Procurement officers are required to investigate and encourage supply of ANZ goods.
(5) Yes.
(6) RAM complies with Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines see (3) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment and Heritage Portfolio: Procurement Policies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2387)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) As an example of paper consumption within my portfolio, my department and portfolio agencies used approximately 30,000 reams of office paper and 130 boxes of continuous computer paper in the 1999/2000 financial year.
(2) My department and portfolio agencies have in place guidelines and working documents that reflect the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles.

(3) No standard methodology or weighting is applied by my department and portfolio agencies. Each individual procurement has selection criteria that seek to ensure that best value for money is attained and that other requirements in the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles are adhered to.
(4) See answer to question 3. It should be noted that procurement by my department and portfolio agencies is generally sourced from within Australia and/or New Zealand.
My department and portfolio agencies comply with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles.
(6) See answers to questions 4 and 5.

subdebateinfo.title: Foreign Affairs and Trade Portfolio: Procurement Policies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2390)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely, (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethic and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provisions of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Departments or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question in relation to the portfolio of Foreign Affairs and Trade is as follows:

quote.para: (1) In 1999-2000 the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio purchased approximately 48,000 reams of Australian-made paper in Canberra.
(2) Portfolio agencies' in-house procurement instructions accord fully with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines (CPGs).
(3) The core principles underpin all procurement activity within the portfolio. They are contained in all instructions and guidelines provided to all staff involved in procurement.
(4) The portfolio does not discriminate against ANZ suppliers. Standard tender documentation encourages ANZ suppliers to bid and in some instances, only ANZ suppliers are invited to bid.
(5) Standard tender documentation requires potential suppliers to supply only ANZ products wherever possible or identify the ANZ content of the goods to be supplied.
(6) Portfolio methodologies conform fully with Commonwealth Procurement Policy.

subdebateinfo.title: Finance and Administration Portfolio: Procurement Policies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2392)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are Agencies within the Portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and Agencies with the Portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and Agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or Agencies within the Portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide and appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Portfolio consumes office paper. Consumption fluctuates throughout the year and is dependant upon timing and the particular activities being undertaken.

(2) All procurement within my Portfolio is carried out in accordance with both the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles 1998 and the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997. As advised in the 1999-2000 DOFA Annual Report, to enhance compliance of the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines, an explanation of their importance in providing fundamental directions for government procurement was included in DOFA's Chief Executive Instructions.

(3) In accordance with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles 1998, the Portfolio follows the core principles of government procurement as a means to efficiently and effectively deliver the Government's programmes.

(4) In line with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles 1998, the Portfolio's tender documentation promotes the development of ANZ industry by means that are consistent with the achievement of value for money objectives.
(5) See answer to Question (4).

(6) In accordance with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines: Core Policies and Principles 1998, the Portfolio follows the core principles of government procurement as a means to efficiently and effectively deliver the Government's programmes.
In accordance with annual reporting requirements, the Portfolio reports against an âAssessment of Performance against Purchasing Policiesâ.
For the 1990 -2000 Annual Report, DOFA advised the following:

âThe Internal Audit Unit conducts probity reviews of DOFA's contracting arrangements to ensure compliance with the general probity principles of the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines and Chief Executive Instructions. During 1999-2000, Internal Audit conducted 180 probity reviews within DOFA. All reviews ensured a defensible purchasing outcome in accordance with Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines and supporting policy and principlesâ.

subdebateinfo.title: Industry, Science and Resources Portfolio: Procurement Policies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2394)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

para.inline: The Department of Industry, Science and Resources

quote.para: (1) The Department of Industry, Science and Resources purchases and consumes approximately $140,000 of office paper per annum for printing, faxing and photocopying.

(2) The Department's Chief Executive Instructions specify that Purchasing Officials should comply with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. The Department's Procedural Rules, which contain more detailed guidance, specify the core principles and policies of procurement and detail the website for accessing the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines proper.
(3) The Department does not apply a weighting or methodology to any particular principle of the guidelines. The Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines treat all the principles with equal importance.

(4) No criteria is used to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete for goods and services with the Department. However, the Department's Procedural Rules specify that wherever possible Purchasing Officials should actively seek out ANZ suppliers. This does not mean discriminating against foreign suppliers, but giving ANZ suppliers the opportunity to compete.

(5) Suppliers are not advised that they must offer ANZ goods. The Department complies with Government policy not to draw up contracts so as to exclude ANZ goods, nor to evaluate tenders in a manner that is biased against ANZ suppliers.

(6) The Department currently conducts contract management training which addresses the key principles of the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. It also ensures its staff are fully conversant with the Chief Executive Instructions, Procedural Rules and Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines in conducting all forms of purchasing activity.
(1) IP Australia is a moderately large purchaser and consumer of paper, commensurate with the size of the organisation.

(2) IP Australia has an accredited Central Purchasing Unit, which oversights adherence to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines throughout the organisation. It is staffed by accredited purchasing officers. IP Australia also has Chief Executive Instructions relating to purchasing that supplement the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(3) (a) IP Australia uses weighted evaluation criteria to assess tenders on the basis of value for money.
(b) The IP Australia procurement instructions have benchmarks based on the estimated value of the purchases for determining the most effective and practical method of seeking quotes and tenders.
(c) Staff involved in purchasing attend courses in procurement ethics and the Central Purchasing Unit oversights issues of ethics and fair dealings throughout the organisation.
(d) IP Australia has Chief Executive Instructions to cover purchasing and reports purchases of more that $2000 in the Commonwealth Gazette.
(e) IP Australia supports the development of ANZ industry as set out in the responses to Question 4 and 5.
(f) IP Australia supports Commonwealth policies as set out in Section 6 of the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

(4) IP Australia structures its tendering strategies to ensure ANZ suppliers have a fair opportunity to complete and to seek out ANZ products consistent with achieving value for money wherever possible.

(5) IP Australia buys ANZ products where they represent the best value for money. For instance, we negotiated with the preferred tenderer for the supply of stationery to use an Australian manufacturer for the organisation's bulk paper supplies.
(6) IP Australia has policies and practices in place to achieve compliance with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(1) The Australian Geological Survey Organisation (AGSO) is not a large purchaser or consumer of office paper.

(2) As a prescribed agency under the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997, AGSO has established a set of Chief Executive Instructions (CEIs) governing day to day purchasing activity and policy. The CEIs follow the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(3) AGSO's CEIs do not require that a percentage weighting be given to the core principles in the procurement guidelines, nor do the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines require such an approach.

(4) As stated above, weightings are not required. In all AGSO procurement, the principles of value for money, open and effective competition and support for industry are observed at all times. Open and effective competition is the main vehicle for ensuring opportunity to compete.

(5) As stated above, AGSO follows the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines through its CEIs. AGSO's Request for Tender documentation includes reference to the Commonwealth's requirement in respect of Australian and New Zealand supplies.
(6) The Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines do not require the application of weighting to the core principles.

para.inline: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)

quote.para: (1) No, because two thirds of CSIRO is engaged in research and it is not primarily an administrative body. Specific information on paper purchases and consumption is not available without significant resources being allocated to contacting each of CSIRO's sixty sites.

(2 to 6) As an agency under the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, CSIRO is not subject to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. However, the key principles of the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines are included in the CSIRO procurement policy.

The prime objective of CSIRO's purchasing activity is to provide goods and services to support CSIRO's functions while obtaining value for money and while adhering to CSIRO policy. The Government's policy, which is intended to give increased access for Australian and New Zealand suppliers of goods and services, is included in CSIRO's procurement policy.

The most cost effective method of purchasing is chosen for each occasion depending on what is being bought, the value of the purchase, and the range of potential suppliers. In most cases this is achieved through obtaining multiple quotes, a formal tender process for purchases in excess of $50k, or accessing Government contracts. The resources needed to make the purchase is commensurate with the value, importance and complexity of the purchase.

In order to maintain a reputation for fair and impartial dealing with suppliers and with those who bid for contracts to supply goods and services, CSIRO's policy requires the demonstration of high ethical standards and openness in the competitive acquisition process, commercial confidentiality, accountability, ensuring that there is fair and open competition, and (subject to the need for economy and efficiency) ensuring that all those who wish to and might be capable of supplying goods and services are given the opportunity to bid.

In order to obtain value for money, there must be open and effective competition, clear specification or statement of requirements, and selection criteria preferably performance oriented and focussing on the outcome expected rather than specifying a particular way of satisfying the requirement.
(1) The National Standards Commission is a small purchaser of office paper, with expenditure estimated at $4,000 per annum.
(2 to 6) As an Agency under the Commonwealth Authorities and Company Act 1997 the National Standards Commission is not subject to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

The Commission's purchasing is based on value for money. It has included in it most recent Certified Agreement guidelines on official conduct which underpin all activities with a number of principles and values similar to those that apply in the APS to ethical and fair dealing.
The small scale of the Commissions operation means it seldom goes to tender, with most purchasing the subject of competitive quotations from local businesses.
(1) The Australian Sports Commission (ASC) is not a large purchaser or consumer of office papers: its annual expenditure on these goods is about $45,000.

(2 to 6) As an agency covered by the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, the ASC is not required to adhere to Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. However, the ASC procurement procedures generally comply with the guidelines.
(1) The Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) purchases approximately, 650 reams of plain paper per annum and 80 reams of printed letterhead per annum.
(2 to 6) As an agency under the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, ASDA is not subject to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(1) The Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) is a small purchaser of office paper.
(2 to 6) As an agency under the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, the ATC is not subject to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.
(1) The Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) is a small purchaser/consumer of office papers with expenditure of approximately $15,000pa.

(2 to 6) As an agency under the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, AIMS is not subject to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. However, AIMS Purchasing Policy is consistent with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

AIMS Purchasing Policy requires that all purchases over the value of $30,000 must go to public tender, which facilitates compliance with the principles which underpin these procurement guidelines. In addition, each purchase over $100,000 must be referred to the Minister for review and approval.
AIMS promotes the purchases of local and ANZ goods as a preference.
(1) The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) currently uses approximately 14,000 reams of office paper per annum.

(2 to 6) As an agency under the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, ANSTO is not subject to the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. However ANSTO's purchasing policy is broadly consistent with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

ANSTO continually evaluates samples provided by suppliers, which facilitates compliance with the principles that underpin the procurement guidelines. Quality and value are the prime criteria. If an Australian/New Zealand supplier can consistently meet these requirements, ANSTO will purchase from that supplier.
ANSTO uses the following standard clause in procurement documentation:

ANZ Preference - In the provision of Supplies the Contractor shall not exclude Australian or New Zealand goods and services that are suitable, or adaptable to ANSTO's needs, and shall give the fullest consideration to purchasing Australian and New Zealand Supplies representing value for money.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: For the purpose of answering the question office papers have been defined as photocopy and printer paper used to generate correspondence.
(1) During the 12 month period 1 March 2000 to 28 February 2001 the Department consumed an estimated 27,000 reams of photocopy and printer paper.
(2) The Department's Chief Executive Instructions on Purchasing reflect Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines and staff are required to comply with them when undertaking purchasing activities.

(3) The Department does not use a standard methodology or weighting criteria to determine the importance of the core principles, which underpin the procurement guidelines. However, in respect of the purchase of photocopy and printer paper, the Department treated all the core principles as mandatory.
(4) The Department places a mandatory requirement on the paper being made in Australia and New Zealand.
(5) Yes, it is a requirement of the procurement process.

(6) The Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines are seen as an important part of the procurement process and the Department has issued instructions which reflect the Guidelines. An intranet site is also being developed which will ensure that staff involved in procurement activities are fully aware of their responsibilities in relation to Commonwealth procurement policy.
(1) During the 12 month period 1 March 2000 to 28 February 2001 the Tribunal consumed an estimated 6,000 reams of photocopy and printer paper.
(2) The Tribunal's Chief Executive Instructions on Purchasing reflect Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines and staff are required to comply with them when undertaking purchasing activities.

(3) The Tribunal does not use a standard methodology or weighting criteria to determine the importance of the core principles, which underpin the procurement guidelines. However, in respect of the purchase of photocopy and printer paper, the Tribunal treated all the core principles as mandatory.

(4) The Tribunal encourages suppliers to offer paper manufactured in Australia and New Zealand on competitive terms to foreign made paper. However, there have been occasions where the on-balance value of foreign made papers has resulted in small purchases of foreign made paper. Most of the Tribunal's paper purchases are of Australian made paper.
(5) Yes, it is a requirement of the procurement process.

(6) The Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines are seen as an important part of the procurement process and the Tribunal has issued instructions which reflect the Guidelines. An intranet site is also being developed which will ensure that staff involved in procurement activities are fully aware of their responsibilities in relation to Commonwealth procurement policy and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's Chief Executive Instructions.

The Bureau is a small intergovernmental agency, partly funded within the Australian Federal Police (AFP) appropriation, that for efficiency purposes utilises AFP standing contracts where appropriate. This includes office paper purchases. Records indicate that the Bureau has consistently purchased Australian and New Zealand paper.
(4) Refer (3).
(5) Not applicable.
(6) The Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines are seen as an important part of the procurement process and the Bureau utilises the AFP intranet that provides instructions and links on the Guidelines.

However, in respect of the purchase of photocopy and printer paper, the AFP tender process and evaluation criteria were underpinned by all the core principles.

(4) In evaluating the tender for the supply of stationery, tenderers were required to provided details of content or Australian and New Zealand origin, of each item. This training program is also supported by an Intranet site which has a link to the Department of Finance and Administration Competitive and Contracting website.
