subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Portfolio: Procurement Policies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2398)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are the Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) AFFA's Chief Executive Instruction on âProcurement of Goods and Servicesâ includes advice that the âCommonwealth Procurement Guidelines are to be observed when purchasing goods and servicesâ.

(3) AFFA bases its purchasing on the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. There is no methodology or weighting criteria for the importance of the core principles, however, a weighting may be applied to some evaluation criteria.

(4) While taking into account the issue of providing opportunities for Australian and New Zealand industry, AFFA also takes into account other principles such as value for money, ensuring an efficient, effective and ethical use of funds.
(5) As above.

(7) Checks of compliance with government policy are undertaken through several avenues. For example, through internal audit reviews, ANAO reviews, gazettal of contracts over $2000 and the Annual Report. In addition, the services of probity auditors are utilised, where necessary, to ensure compliance with government policy.

subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services Portfolio: Procurement Policies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2399)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister's Department, or are agencies within the portfolio, large purchasers or consumers of office papers.
(2) How are Commonwealth procurement guidelines being adhered to by the Minister's Department and agencies within the portfolio.

(3) What methodology or weighting criteria does the Minister's Department and agencies use to determine the importance of the core principles which underpin the procurement guidelines, namely (a) value for money, (b) open and effective competition, (c) ethics and fair dealing, (d) accountability and reporting, (e) national competitiveness and industry development and (f) support for other Commonwealth policies.

(4) What weighting criteria are used to implement the mandatory provisions in the guidelines which state that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australia New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete.
(5) In inviting suppliers to tender for the provision of goods, are suppliers advised that they must offer ANZ goods.

(6) If the Minister's Department or agencies within the portfolio do not have weighting criteria for determining the principles, will the Minister take steps to ensure that they provide an appropriate means to demonstrate their compliance with Commonwealth procurement policy.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Commonwealth procurement guidelines are the basis for a range of internal policy documents relating to procurement in the Family and Community Services portfolio (which includes the Department, Centrelink, Child Support Agency, CRS Australia, Social Security Appeals Tribunal, and the Australian Institute of Family Studies). The documents include the Chief Executive Instructions, procurement manuals and tender and contract templates, Centrelink publications such as âBuying Mattersâ and âBuying Matters Moreâ and CRS Australia's Purchasing and Contracts Policies and Procedures manual and standard offer documentation. The Child Support Agency purchases a wide range of services including office papers from the ATO, which follows the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. In addition to these documents, FaCS agencies have specialist staff who provide advice on all major purchasing activities.

(3) The Commonwealth procurement guidelines, which lay down the core procurement principles, make no distinction between the principles in terms of priority. All internal documents and procurement processes within the portfolio give equal weight to each principle. No principle is considered superior to any other.

(4) The requirement that agencies must be able to demonstrate that Australian and New Zealand (ANZ) suppliers have had a fair opportunity to compete is implemented by Family and Community Services portfolio in three ways. First, by a requirement that ANZ suppliers are not to be discriminated against by the use of inappropriate specification of requirements. Second, by a requirement to give fullest consideration to ANZ goods and services representing value for money. Third, by the use of the Industrial Supplies Office as a source of information on potential ANZ suppliers. This is reflected in portfolio internal documents in accordance with the Commonwealth procurement guidelines.

(5) Potential suppliers are generally provided with information about Commonwealth policy on the offering of ANZ goods, as detailed in Commonwealth procurement guidelines. Mandating the supply of ANZ goods would be in contravention of the core principles laid down in the Commonwealth procurement guidelines.

(6) Application of all internal instructions, manuals, tender and contract templates and other relevant documents and procurement processes within the portfolio is subject to on-going monitoring by specialist staff, and public scrutiny through the publication of details of contracts arranged.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) What performance indicators and quality control procedures have been introduced in relation to the work done by trade repair organisations which was formerly performed at South Queensland Logistic Group.
(2) What comparisons have been made of the quality and cost-effectiveness of this trade work with previous in-house work.
(3) What conclusions or findings have been reached as a result of these comparisons.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Northern Logistic Group has both a performance evaluation system and a quality system. All repair and maintenance activity is subject to monthly performance review against a range of performance indicators. The unit employs a contemporary quality assurance approach to ensuring the quality of work performed externally. This approach includes random and programmed audits throughout the entire repair and maintenance process. The work was not necessarily formerly performed in-house as Northern Logistic Group has always utilised a combination of both internal and external repair.

(2) There is continuous evaluation of the cost effectiveness and quality of all repair and maintenance work for which Northern Logistic Group is responsible. In addition to cost, factors such as workshop capacity and capability, turnaround time and ability to source and supply repair parts impact on the decision to conduct repairs either internally or externally.

(3) The conclusion reached from evaluation of workshop capacity and capability is that local industry has far greater resources that can be applied to repair and maintenance tasks managed by Northern Logistic Group. To best satisfy the requirements of the regional dependency, a combination of external and internal capabilities will continue to be utilised. Both internal and external processes have proven capable of delivering to the required quality standard.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Since 1 July 2000, has Defence identified or become aware of any cases where the private contractor for vehicle maintenance for work from the South Queensland Logistic Group has forwarded a bill for work that has not been done.
(2) If so, on how many occasions did this occur and who was the contractor on each occasion.
(3) What action was taken to rectify the vehicle and when.
(4) Who paid for the rectification.
(5) What penalties were imposed on the contractor and when.
(6) Does Defence still use that contractor.
(7) What inspections or processes were in place to identify these errors.
(8) Have any changes been made to these inspection procedures since June 2000: if so, (a) what changes have been made, (b) by whose authority were they made (c) when were they made.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Since 1 July 2000 Northern Logistic Group, formerly known as South Queensland Logistic Group has completed 1024 Work Orders for vehicular repair through the use of private contractors. One invoice for vehicle maintenance work was received where a lubrication task was included on the invoice but had only partly been completed.
(2) This has occurred on one occasion only. The contractor was Daimler Chrysler.
(3) The contractor was informed and the matter rectified immediately.
(4) The rectification was wholly at the contractors expense.
(5) No penalties were imposed on the contractor.
(6) Daimler Chrysler is the Original Equipment Manufacturers representative, has a national contract for supply of repair parts and continues to be used throughout Defence.

(7) Northern Logistic Group employs a contemporary quality assurance approach to ensuring the quality of work performed externally. This approach includes random and programmed audits throughout the entire repair and maintenance process.

(8) A programmed system audit of the entire Repair process was conducted in October 2000. There have been no changes to inspection procedures as a result of this audit or any other review since 1 July 2000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) In the answer to question No. 1813 (Hansard, 4 October 2000, page 20853), was it indicated that Defence played no role in determining wages and personnel management matters for contractors' employees at the Bulimba barracks.

(2) If so, why then did Army or Defence personnel provide advice to CMAS Consulting on the suitability of former staff when it gained the contract for the supply of labour at Enoggera and SQLG, as outlined in the reply to question No. 2188 (Hansard, 6 February 2001, page 20913).

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. The answer stated that `Defence plays no role in negotiations concerning conditions for contractors' employees.'

(2) Army or Defence staff of Northern Logistic Group (NLG) did not play a role in negotiations concerning conditions for prospective CMAS Consulting employees. As answered in Parliamentary Question on Notice No. 2188, `Defence staff were requested by CMAS Consulting to provide verbal referee comment on Drake Industrial employees that CMAS Consulting was considering recruiting for employment at Bulimba. Referee comment was sought from military supervisors on two criteria: standard of work, and length of time on site.' No additional information was sought by CMAS Consulting or provided by Army or Defence staff.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1283 (Hansard, 27 February 2001, page 21301) in which he said information is not available against the categories of dates specified in the answer, what information is available to the Government regarding (a) full time, (b) part time and (c) casual staff employed by the Commonwealth in (i) Tasmania and (ii) the electoral division of Denison and for what dates is it available.
(2) Why was the specific information sought by me not available.
(3) What is the best information available to the Government regarding the categories of employment for those closest to those sought by me.
(4) Why did it take approximately 11 months for him to respond to my question with a reply to the effect that the information would not be provided.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I am advised by my department as follows:

(1) The honourable member has asked for information in relation to `Commonwealth employment'. In addition to encompassing people employed under the Public Service Act 1999 (the Public Service Act) in the Australian Public Service (the APS), the description `Commonwealth employment' also extends to ongoing and non-ongoing employment in non-APS entities in the form of Government Business Enterprises such as Telstra and Australia Post and to elements which have left the APS but which have continued within the Commonwealth such as Health Services Australia and Australian Hearing Services.

Details of all employment by the Commonwealth Government are not held centrally. The Public Service and Merit Protection Commission (PSMPC) collects data on APS employment, but it does not collect data on employment in these non-APS Commonwealth entities, nor does it collect data on casual employment. In relation to APS employment in Tasmania, between 1995/96 and 1998/99 the PSMPC collected data on the number of persons being paid from Tasmanian pay centres. In 1999/2000, the collection method changed to the number of persons physically located in Tasmania. This data is publicly available in the PSMPC's Statistical Bulletin for each of the financial years. The PSMPC does not collect data specifically relating to APS employment in the electoral division of Denison.

(2) The specific information sought by the honourable member could only have been obtained by survey of Commonwealth departments and agencies that might employ staff in Tasmania. I was not prepared to authorise the diversion of resources that would have been required to conduct such a survey.

(3) In his Question on Notice No.1283, the honourable member asked for information current as at 2 March 1996 and March 2000. APS employment data collected by the PSMPC on the bases described above is available for a range of dates up to June 2000, but 31 March 1996 and 30 June 2000 are the dates closest to the those sought by the honourable member. As at 31 March 1996, the number of on-going APS employees whose pay centre was located in Tasmania was 2,769, which was 2.1 per cent of on-going APS employees at that time. As at 30 June 2000, the number of APS employees physically located in Tasmania was 1721, representing 1.7 percent of on-going APS employees. It is important to note that the difference between the two sets of figures does not necessarily reflect a decline in absolute numbers in Commonwealth employment but rather a change in the statistical methodology. Additionally, and as indicated previously, staff at Health Services Australia and Australian Hearing Services are no longer APS employees although they have remained in Commonwealth employment.
(4) Consideration was given and discussions were held on ways to compile the data sought by the honourable member leading to a conclusion that the expense and effort involved could not be justified.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: What will he do to ensure the ongoing availability of staff and resources to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or other administrative agencies given Parliament's rejection of his amalgamation proposal.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The existing tribunals which would have been replaced by the Administrative Review Tribunal (ART) will continue to operate as usual. The terms of appointments of a number of AAT members will cease on 30 June 2001. I will be taking appropriate steps to ensure that the AAT has adequate membership to ensure its continuing operation. There are a number of members whose tenure continues beyond 30 June 2001 and their situation is not affected.
Appropriate staffing levels will be maintained, and other resources allocated, to enable the tribunal to meet existing workloads beyond 1 July 2001.

In relation to the other tribunals that were to be incorporated into the ART, the responsible Ministers will take the necessary steps in relation to membership, staff and other resources to ensure their continuity.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney Airports Corporation Ltd: Pricing Proposal and Legal Action
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2418)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Given that the scoping study of the sale of Sydney Airport is due for completion shortly, will the ACCC decision on the SACL aeronautical pricing proposal be finally resolved before the sale.
(2) When is the Productivity Commission review of the price regulation of airport services due for completion and will it be completed before the sale.
(3) When are the airlines' legal actions against SACL due to be heard by the Federal Court.
(4) What is the basis of the legal actions and is it the intended that the sale proceed before this legal action is completed.

talk.start.para: âThe Acting Minister for Finance and Administration has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The ACCC has issued a draft decision. A final decision is expected before the sale is concluded.

(2) I am advised that the Productivity Commission is due to deliver its final report on its review of price regulation of airport services on 21 December 2001. The sale of Sydney Airport is expected to be concluded in the second half of 2001.
(3) I understand that legal action commenced by the airlines against SACL in relation to the SA2000 project will not be heard until November 2001 at the earliest.
(4) I am unable to comment on matters currently the subject of court action. The sale of Sydney Airport is expected to be concluded in the second half of 2001.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission: Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd.
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2419)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) With respect to the draft decision of the ACCC relating to the Sydney Airport Corporation Limited aeronautical pricing proposal released on 16 February 2001 and requiring responses by 5 March 2001, did he or his Department receive complaints about this deadline and the short amount of time available to prepare responses; if so, from whom.
(2) Who made the decision to impose this deadline and why.
(3) Did he consider an extension of time; if so, why was it rejected.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) The decision to require responses by 5 March 2001 was made by the ACCC as part of its assessment process. The public consultation process extended over a five month period and followed a consultation process between Sydney Airport and airport users of almost a year.
In setting the deadline for responses the ACCC advises me that it weighed up the potential benefits from extending the process against the need for a timely response to SACL's proposals.
(3) See answer to (2).

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission: Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd.
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2420)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) With respect to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's (ACCC) decision on the aeronautical pricing proposal by the Sydney Airport Corporation Limited (SACL), what information has the ACCC refused to release to enable the Board of Airline Representatives (BARA) to comment and what was the justification for the ACCC's refusal to release such information.

(2) What was the nature of the information provided by SACL to the ACCC after the closing date for submissions and was access to that information denied to BARA which would have allowed it to comment on that SACL material; if not, why not.
(3) Was BARA given access to the ACCC's modelling of costs and charges, and was BARA allowed to comment on such modelling; if not, why not.
(4) Was the ACCC's modelling of costs and charges provided to SACL; if so, why was SACL provided such material and BARA not provided with the material.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The ACCC did not release two items to BARA. The first was a report commissioned by Sydney Airport on operating and maintenance costs. The report was prepared by Leigh Fisher Associates. The second was material provided by Sydney Airport to Opus international, consultants to the ACCC.
The Leigh Fisher report was not released to BARA because it contained commercial in confidence information.

In relation to the material provided by Sydney Airport to Opus international the ACCC considered that to obtain and then release the information would unnecessarily delay the assessment process and the information sought was not material to the final outcome of the ACCC's considerations.
(2) SACL provided updated traffic forecasts to the ACCC after the closing date for submissions. This followed a request from the ACCC.
The updated traffic forecasts have been made available to BARA. BARA was invited to provide comments on the information provided.
(3) BARA was given access to the ACCC's modelling of costs and charges and was invited to comment on it.
(4) Both SACL and BARA were given access to the ACCC's modelling of costs and charges.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 1 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Given recent media reports alleging that a group of Sydney lawyers are using bankruptcy to escape their tax debts, has the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and Administration, their offices or Departments consulted him, his office or his Department about action that can be taken to stop such a group of wealthy individuals abusing the tax system by being serial bankrupts.
(2) Does he support proposed changes by the NSW Attorney-General to change State regulations under which barristers who abused the tax system would be disbarred.

(3) Will he consider lobbying other State and Territory governments to introduce regulations similar to that proposed in NSW; if not, why not given the Tax Commissioner's attacks in speeches during 1999 and in his 1999 and 2000 annual reports on professionals abusing the tax system.

(4) Has he, his office or his Department been consulted by any other Minister, Minister's staff or Department concerning how the Government might pursue other professional groups referred to by the Tax Commissioner such as accounting and medical professionals as having five times the average national tax debt due to their policy of abusing the tax system.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I met in March with my colleague the Assistant Treasurer, Senator the Hon Rod Kemp, to discuss a coordinated response to this problem. As a result of that meeting a Task Force of officers was established to examine and report upon the legislative and administrative changes that might be required to deal adequately with the problem. That Task Force includes representatives from my Department, the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia, the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury. It will consult both the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions (Cth) in the course of its deliberations, and with the legal profession.

(2) This is not a precise statement of the changes introduced by the NSW Attorney-General. The NSW Attorney-General has introduced changes to the regulations under the Legal Profession Act 1987 (NSW) to ensure that barristers and solicitors are required to disclose to their professional association any bankruptcy or arrangement with their creditors, as well as details of any criminal convictions (apart from some minor specified exceptions). I support the thrust of the changes that have been introduced by the NSW Attorney-General.

(3) I placed the matter on the agenda for meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in Adelaide on 22-23 March 2001. At that meeting I urged upon my State and Territory colleagues the desirability of adopting a consistent approach to the problem, and that the following elements should be the minimum elements of that response:

answer.para: Â· The mandatory reporting by a legal practitioner to the relevant professional association of his or her bankruptcy; and
Â· A mechanism whereby the relevant professional association applies a `fit and proper person' test to the right of a person, once bankrupt, to practise, or to continue to practise, as a barrister.

quote.para: At the meeting I proposed that a working group of Commonwealth, State and Territory officials be appointed to develop a response to the problem. This proposal was accepted by my State and Territory colleagues.
(4) I am not aware of any such approaches.

subdebateinfo.title: Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations: Vehicle Import Approvals
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2422)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) How many Vehicle Import Approvals (VIAs) under Regulation 9E of the Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations and paragraph 20(1)(b) of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act have been issued in each of the last five years.
(2) How many vehicles were approved under the VIAs, by model and make.
(3) How many VIAs in each year were issued to (a) licenced dealers and (b) individuals.
(4) What sum does the administration of the VIA approval process cost his Department each year.
(5) What procedure is followed and criteria applied when considering a request for a VIA.
(6) What steps does his Department take to ensure compliance with the terms of a VIA and what resources have been spent on this process in each of the past five years.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) VIAs issued under Motor Vehicle Standards Regulation 9E and paragraph 20(1)(b):
(2) Number of vehicles approved under VIAs issued under Motor Vehicle Standards Regulation 9E and paragraph 20(1)(b):
Details of the different makes and models imported over the last five years are provided in the Attachment.
(3) The information requested is not provided to the Department.
(4) Cost estimate for administration of the VIA process for the current financial year is $540 000.
(5) The assessment procedures employed for each VIA application are as follows:
Confirmation the application fee has been paid.
Confirmation that the vehicles for which the import application is made are eligible under Motor Vehicle Standards Regulation 9E.
Confirmation that the applicant is the owner of the vehicle for which application is made by way of an invoice.
Confirmation that the vehicle is of the type described in the application.

Confirmation that the applicant holds a Compliance Plate Approval for the subject vehicle make/model, or the application is accompanied by a Letter of Agreement from a holder of a Compliance Plate Approval for the subject vehicle make/model.

(6) Details of all vehicles are forwarded electronically to the National Exchange of Vehicle and Driver Identification System (NEVDIS) every two days for the information of State and Territory Registering Authorities (STRAs). Irregulaties are generally detected in the first instance by the STRAs and this may lead to an investigation and possibly prosecution. Resources required for this function have not been costed.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission: Chairman
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2423)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 5 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2117 (Hansard, 26 February 2001, page 21217) concerning the remuneration package of the Chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), due to the sensitive nature of the ACCC Chairman's duties, is he required to notify him, his office or his Department in the same way as Members and Senators are required, of any gifts received from official and other than official services and of any sponsored travel or hospitality received including attendance at sporting and cultural events; if not, why not.
(2) Did the Chairman attend the 2000 Olympics as a guest; if so, which events were attended and what was the nature of the hospitality received by the Chairman.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. The Chairman of the ACCC has not been required to notify the Minister, his office or his Department of any gifts or sponsored travel or hospitality received. The Chairman is subject to section 13 of the Public Service Act 1999 (APS Code of Conduct), and the ACCC's Guidelines for Members and Associates, which require that personal benefits accepted be declared for the internal records concerning such matters.
(2) No. I am informed that the Chairman did not attend the 2000 Olympics as a guest.

subdebateinfo.title: Second Sydney Airport: Sydney West Proposal
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2426)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 5 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Can the Minister define what documents constitute the proposal known as Sydney West Airport.
(2) Can the Minister describe the proposal for Sydney West Airport as it presently stands.
(3) Can the Minister describe the impact of the supplementary EIS for Sydney West Airport, made in 1999 on the proposal.
(4) In light of the decisions relating to Bankstown and Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airports on 13 December 2000, has the Minister been advised that the proposal has been withdrawn.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) By Sydney West Airport , I presume that you mean the proposal to construct and operate a second major airport for Sydney at Badgerys Creek which I will now refer to as the Second Sydney Airport Proposal.

The Second Sydney Airport proposal was assessed by my Department in accordance with the Administrative Procedures of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. A Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) was released for public review in December 1997. A Supplement to the Draft EIS, which took account of the public comments received in regard to the Draft EIS, was submitted to my Department in June 1999. My Department completed its assessment of these documents and submitted its advice to me in August 1999. I subsequently conveyed my advice and recommendations in regard to the proposal to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.
(2) The proposal that I considered was that described in the EIS for the Second Sydney Airport Proposal.

(3) The impacts of the Second Sydney Airport Proposal are described in the EIS documents and in my Department's assessment report. These documents, as well as my advice and recommendations to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, are on the public record.
(4) The Government's position on the Second Sydney Airport Proposal was made clear in its announcement of 13 December 2000 on Sydney's future airport needs.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Overseas Visitors
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2431)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Sport and Tourism, upon notice, on 6 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Of the 425 900 overseas visitors in Australia during January 2001, what percentage claimed back the GST incurred on purchases.
(2) Has she received any complaints from international tourists on the logistical problems involved with claiming back GST on goods purchased in Australia; if so, how many.
(3) What, if any, advice is given by her to tourists making these complaints.
(4) Was she consulted in the Government's process of drawing up the guidelines on the GST-rebate for overseas visitors to Australia; if so, what input did she or her Department provide.
(5) Has her attention been drawn to the arrangements the Canadian Government has in place for overseas visitors to have their GST reimbursed.
(6) What public educational measures has she and her Department undertaken to ensure overseas visitors to Australia are aware of the Government's GST reimbursement process.

(7) Do the current arrangements for GST reimbursement for overseas visitors to Australia make it virtually impossible to obtain a refund and constitute a very unfriendly and unhelpful way to treat visitors.
(8) Are the current arrangements a deterrent to overseas visitors and a way to ensure as little of the Government's revenue is returned as possible.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The information requested by the honourable member concerns the Tourist Refund Scheme which is administered by the Australian Customs Service. The Department of Industry, Science and Resources does not gather information on the percentage of GST claimed back on purchases.
(2) Yes. One.
(3) The complaint has been referred to the Australian Customs Service which administers the Tourist Refund Scheme and to the Treasurer who oversights the policy aspects of the Scheme.
(4) Yes. The input was in the nature of confidential policy advice to the Minister.
(5) Yes.

(6) The Australian Customs Service has prime responsibility for promoting the Tourist Refund Scheme on behalf of the Government. The Australian Tourist Commission plays a supporting role in the delivery of the communications strategy by helping in the distribution of pamphlets and other literature through its international offices.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Aircraft Approach Trial
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2432)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2154 (Hansard, 26 February 2001, page 24464) concerning Ansett's low-noise approach technique involving aircraft on descent into Sydney using minimum power, should the evaluation of the STAR approach go ahead after the completion of the trial of the Precision Runway Monitor System; if not, why not.
(2) Will that evaluation test consideration of whether the proposal helps minimise greenhouse emissions.
(3) Has he encouraged Airservices Australia to continue to work on its procedure to trial power off STAR approaches for northerly arrivals at Sydney Airport.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(2) The details of the evaluation have yet to be determined.

(3) Yes. Power-off approaches are one of the last remaining elements of the Airport's Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) that have yet to be implemented. The Government is committed to power-off approaches being trialed at Sydney Airport.

subdebateinfo.title: Textile, Clothing and Footwear Strategic Investment Program Scheme: Bradmill Undare Group
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2433)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 6 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) What action has been taken by the Government to assess whether the Bradmill Undare Group's application for assistance under the $700 million Textile Clothing and Footwear Strategic Investment Program Scheme (SIPS) would meet the guidelines for this scheme.
(2) Following the ordinary procedure, when would an assessment be made.
(3) If the application does meet the guidelines, has a decision been made by the Government as to the quantum of any future grant to Bradmill; if not, when would it ordinarily be made.

(4) How quickly can the Government indicate in writing to Bradmill, for the purposes of providing to the administrators, bank or potential purchasers, the amount to be paid and the time it will be paid.

(5) Has the Government refused two requests by Bradmill for assistance prior to the appointment of administrators for (a) advance payment of SIPS and (b) a quicker decision on how much could be paid and when.
(6) Had an assessment been made prior to Wednesday, 28 February 2001 by the Government about whether earlier payment of SIPS money would or could have prevented the appointment of administrators.

(7) Does AusIndustry advise on the Department of Industry, Science and Resources website that early advice on entitlement to a grant or an advance ruling on entitlement cannot be made and that no provision for advance payments can be made; if so, what prevents the Government from providing the advice.
(8) Is the Textile Clothing and Footwear Strategic Investment Scheme 1999 formulated by the Minister; if so, is it in his power to alter the Scheme.

(9) Now that administrators have been appointed, what discussions has the Government had with the administrators to ascertain whether confirmation of quantum and timing of any future payment, or an earlier payment, would assist in keeping the business running as an ongoing concern or securing a buyer for the plant.
(10) Is the Government prepared in these circumstances and in order to save jobs, to bring SIPS payments to the Bradmill Undare Group forward.

(11) Given the unemployment rate in the City of Maribyrnong, where the Yarraville plant is based, was 12.4% in September 2000 and the devastating impact the closure would have on employment in the region, will the Government consider a discretionary payment under the Regional Assistance Program similar to how that Program has been used for other national projects.

(12) Does the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business Fact Sheet on the Regional Assistance Program (RAP) refer to the program being used for responding to structural adjustments and economic or business downturns; if so, will the Government treat Bradmill as coming within the guidelines.
(13) If Bradmill is forced to close, what arrangements will the Government make for re-training, counselling and job placement services for the Bradmill workers.

(14) Does the Fact Sheet on RAP state that funding is available for assistance in training and job seeking for workers facing retrenchment where such retrenchments could have substantial impact on the regional labour market; if so, will the Government treat Bradmill as coming within these guidelines.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) To be registered, the requirements set out in the legislated TCF (SIP) Scheme need to be met. These requirements were assessed in the normal course of events and four separate entities in the Bradmill Undare Group (Bradmill Textiles Pty Ltd, Undare (Aust) Pty Ltd, Ararat Weaving Pty Ltd and Yarraville Textiles Pty Ltd) have been duly registered.
Assessment of actual grant amounts, however, is the last process undertaken and follows lodgement and assessment of a claim.

(2) Assessment of grant eligibility does not occur until the claim assessment stage. The earliest the Bradmill Group entities could submit a claim for the first program year (2000/01) and the pre-program years (1998/99 & 1999/00) is 1 July 2001.

(3) No decision can be made on Bradmill's grant entitlement until their claim is lodged and assessed and they request a determination of their entitlement to be paid a grant in respect of their claim.

(4) The amount to be paid will not be known until the company seeks a determination of grant entitlement following claim assessment. It will up to the company to seek a determination following a claim assessment. The Scheme requires payment to be made as soon as practicable after a request is made.

(5) Bradmill first approached the Government seeking early payment of its TCF (SIP) Scheme grants in February 2000 to help meet cash-flow difficulties. At a subsequent meeting with the Government in April 2000 the issue was again raised by representatives of Bradmill. On both occasions the company was advised that the TCF (SIP) scheme legislation provided for payment in arrears and therefore the Government was not able to meet Bradmill's request.

Bradmill contacted the Government on Friday 23 February 2001 before receivers were appointed advising that assistance was required by noon the following Monday 26 February 2001. It was not possible for assistance from TCF (SIP) to be provided within that timeframe.

(6) Yes. The Government understands that the potential TCF (SIP) claim from the Bradmill Group is relatively small in relation to the debt due to the creditor which was responsible for the appointment of the Receiver. There has been no suggestion that earlier payment of TCF (SIP) grants would have prevented the appointment of the Receiver.

(7) Yes. In line with the self assessment nature of the Scheme, it is the Department's policy that no pre-claim rulings on grant entitlement will be given in relation to any entity. However, to assist in the self assessment process, guidance is available from AusIndustry. Nevertheless, it is up to entities to obtain their own advice if they consider there is doubt about the eligibility of activities or expenditures on which they intend to base their claims.

(8) Yes. The Textile, Clothing and Footwear Strategic Investment Program Scheme 1999 (TCF (SIP) Scheme) is formulated by the Minister pursuant to section 8 of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Strategic Investment Program Act 1999. Section 34 of the Act provides that the TCF (SIP) Scheme may be varied, but not revoked, in accordance with subsection 33(3) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

(9) The Government is sympathetic to the difficulties of the company and to providing what assistance it can. The Department of Industry Science and Resources is in contact with the receivers. The focus of these discussions has been on the possibility of providing early access to the SIP scheme.

The Department's advice is that any early access will make no difference to the decisions of the receivers as to the future of the Bradmill Undare Group. The Receivers have put the Group up for sale either as a whole or as separate parts.

(10) The Government has already indicated that it is sympathetic to the situation and will act constructively to assist in this situation. Amendments to the SIP Scheme are being considered with the objective of assisting the Bradmill Group and firms in similar situations.

The future of Bradmill and its workers, however, depends on the sale of the business and the decisions of its new owners. The Government understands that at least parts of the Bradmill business continue to trade well.

(11) The fundamental purpose of the Regional Assistance Programme (RAP) is to generate employment in metropolitan, regional and remote Australia by encouraging local community action to boost business growth and create sustainable jobs. The major element of the programme concerns community-based projects aimed at generating jobs and business growth in local areas with a particular focus on building the skills base of a region.

The national projects element of the RAP supports projects of national significance and also enables government to respond on a case by case basis to situations such as natural disasters or local economic crises in areas where business closures have a devastating impact on a small, specialised economy.

Should the Bradmill plant close, the Government would need to consider a full range of options, including potential employment opportunities which might be available in the broader Melbourne labour market.

(12) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, which administers the RAP, is not aware of the `Fact Sheet'. The RAP has published guidelines that are available on the Department's website.
(13) If Bradmill is forced to close, Bradmill workers will receive the full range of assistance available to job seekers through Job Network members.
(14) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is not aware of this `Fact Sheet'. The RAP has published guidelines that are available on the Department's website.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) How have the 1995 amendments to the Family Law Act impacted upon the rate at which mothers and fathers have been granted residence (custody) orders by the Family Court.
(2) What steps is he taking to ensure that the needs of women and men are being addressed equally under the Family Law Act.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Family Court of Australia has provided statistics on custody/residence order outcomes from 1993-94 to 1999-2000. The statistics tell us the numbers of orders granted each year, the numbers of orders granted in favour of fathers, mothers, joint custody/split residence and other applicants, and the percentage of total orders granted for each outcome:
Table: Custody/Residence Order Outcomes - 1993-94 to 1999-00*

entry.para: *Notes:Orders made in the Family Court of Western Australia are excluded, as data is not available.Data for Darwin Registry have been available only since 1996-97.Figures include both orders made by consent and orders made as a result of contested hearings.The concepts were changed from custody and access to parental responsibility by the Family Law Reform Act 1995 which was proclaimed on 11 June 1996.âJointâ custody/residence is where the order is for each child to spend some time residing with each parent and âsplitâ custody/residence is where the order is for each parent to have one or more of their children residing with them on a full time basis.

quote.para: The statistics cannot tell us the impact of the 1995 reforms on these outcomes. Several factors, including the introduction of simplified procedures by the Family Court in 1996 and the increase in unrepresented litigants have impacted on the outcomes of applications for parenting orders, to an extent which is difficult to measure.

However, the raw data shows a steady increase since 1994-95 in the number of residence orders made in favour of fathers. In 1999-2000 almost 20% of residence orders were made in favour of fathers, compared to almost 16% of custody orders in 1994-95.

(2) The provisions of the Family Law Act 1975, pursuant to which the Family Court is required to make decisions, apply to men and women equally. The Court evaluates individual cases on the basis of the evidence before it, and this inevitably involves a balancing process. However, protecting the best interests of a child, or children, involved must remain the overriding concern.

The Family Law Amendment Act 2000 introduced a three stage process designed to protect the welfare of children of separated parents whilst at the same time preventing, or significantly reducing, the stress brought about by parents using contact issues as a means of continuing conflict with their former partner.
The three stages are:

answer.para: Â· preventative measures, to improve communication between separated parents and educating parents about their respective responsibilities in relation to their children;
Â· remedial measures, to enable the parents to resolve issues of conflict about parenting; and
Â· punitive measures, to ensure that, with continuing non-compliance, a parent is punished for deliberate disregard of a court order.

quote.para: In addition to the above measures, as a joint initiative with the Minister for Family and Community Services, I have established a high-level advisory group to find ways to improve the pathways through the family law system. The Family Law Pathways Advisory Group was established in May 2000 and has consulted all the key players in the family law system. The Group has met on five occasions and is due to report to Government shortly on the issues families face as they move through the system.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Are there currently any unfilled judicial vacancies on the Federal Court; if so, where.
(2) Are any judicial vacancies on the Federal Court due or likely to become vacant in 2001; if so, when and where.
(3) Are there now, or is there likely to be later in 2001, any judicial vacancies on the Federal Court in Western Australia.

(4) What is the usual process by which judicial appointments are made to the Federal Court and does he have portfolio responsibility for proposing to Cabinet the names of proposed new Federal Court judges.
(5) Is the process any different in circumstances in which he is under consideration for such an appointment; if so, how is it different.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The Hon Justice Jane Mathews and the Hon Justice Marcus Einfeld have resigned as judges of the Court in Sydney effective from 6 April and 16 April 2001, respectively. The Hon Justice Margaret Stone was appointed with effect from 9 October 2000 in anticipation of the retirement of Justice Mathews. A replacement appointment for Justice Einfeld is under consideration.
No further resignations are expected this year, nor will any of the Judges of the Court attain the compulsory retirement age of 70 during 2001.
(3) See (1) and (2) above.

(4) As the Minister responsible for the administration of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, I have responsibility for proposing to Cabinet new judicial appointments to the Federal Court. The steps in the process of appointing judges to the Federal Court are as follows:

(i) I consult personally with the Chief Justice of the Federal Court, other members and former members of the judiciary, members of the legal profession and others in relation to a proposed appointment.
(ii) The appointment is considered by Cabinet.
(iii) The formal appointment is made by the Governor-General in Council.
(5) These circumstances have not arisen.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 7 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) What is the 2000-2001 budget for the Consumer Affairs Division of Treasury.

(2) Is he able to say whether there are any other consumer affairs related allocations in the 2000-2001 Budget in the Treasury or other portfolios; if so, what are the full details of those allocations.
(3) What were the (a) 1999-2000 and (b) 1998-99 budgeted allocations and actual expenditure for the Consumer Affairs Division of Treasury.
(4) What is the current average staff level in the Consumer Affairs Division of Treasury and what were the average staff levels in (a) 2000, (b) 1999 and (c) 1998.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The operational budget (salaries and administrative expenses) for Consumer Affairs Division (CAD) of Treasury in 2000-2001 is $2.828M.

(2) Within Markets Group in Treasury both Consumer Affairs Division and Financial Markets Division have specific consumer affairs related allocations. Approximately $960,000 has been allocated in Financial Markets Division in relation to consumer financial services and markets. It could be expected that other Departments and agencies have specific consumer affairs related allocations. Details of these allocations for 2000-2001 would need to be sought from the specific Departments/agencies.
(3) (a) The budget allocation for 1999-2000 was $2.918M. Actual expenditure was $2.679M.
(b) CAD joined Treasury on 20 October 1998. The budget allocation for the period 20 October 1998 to 30 June 1999 (transferred from DISR) was $2.222M. Actual expenditure was $2.109M.
(4) The current staffing level in CAD is 29. The average staffing levels for previous years are as follows:
(c) 1998 - For the period 20 October 1998 (when CAD joined Treasury) to 31 December 1998, the average staffing level was 30.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation: Consumer Representatives
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2439)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, upon notice, on 7 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Will he provide a list of all of the appointments of consumer representatives he has made in his capacity as Minister for Financial Services and Regulation.
(2) What are the qualifications and experience of the consumer representatives that he has appointed.
(3) What criteria does he use when appointing consumer representatives.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Attachment A lists the current consumer representatives appointed by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation.

(2) Consumer representatives carry a broad range of qualifications and experience which assists them in making objective, merit-based decisions; in negotiating and conciliating; and in exercising sound and fair judgement in the roles they undertake.
(3) The selection criteria used when appointing consumer representatives varies between schemes, but may include:
- interest and expertise in consumer affairs;
- knowledge of the field of interest relevant to the scheme and the regulatory framework, or an ability to gain this knowledge quickly.
CURRENT CONSUMER REPRESENTATIVES
Appointed by the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 7 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Government considering closing registries for the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in Tasmania and the Northern Territory.
(2) Is it a fact that Tasmania has a higher proportion of its population receiving social security benefits than other States and the ACT which will retain registries.
(3) How many hearings were held in Tasmania for the last year for which records are available, compared with those for the ACT.
(4) If the Tasmanian and Northern Territory registries are to close, does the action conflict with the Government's professed commitments to regional and rural Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Government is not considering closing registries of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT) in Tasmania and the Northern Territory. However, as announced by the Attorney-General on 22 March 2001, the Government will continue to consult interest groups about amendments to the legislation that would replace the SSAT and other tribunals with a single independent Administrative Review Tribunal (ART). A consequence of the Government's goal of establishing an ART would be to combine the registries of the various existing tribunals.

(2) As this question appears to be based on an incorrect assumption that the Tasmanian registry of the SSAT will be closed, there is no necessity to provide the details requested which were apparently intended to reinforce an argument against closure of the Tasmanian registry.
(3) During 1999-2000 there were 387 appeals finalised in Tasmania. In the same period there were 327 appeals finalised in Canberra.
(4) In view of the answer to (1), this question is not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 8 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) What funds have been allocated by the Government to structural adjustment in the dairy industry in Australia.
(2) How were these funds raised.
(3) Is the dairy structural adjustment program funded by a levy on drinking milk and by consumers.
(4) What Federal Government funds are in the recent package of assistance to the dairy industry.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Government has allocated $1.78 billion dollars for structural adjustment in the dairy industry.

(2) These funds are being raised through a levy of 11 cents per litre on liquid milk products comprising whole-milk, modified milk, Ultra Heat Treated (UHT) milk and flavoured milk. Sales of imported milk are also covered by the levy.
(3) Yes. The dairy structural adjustment program is being funded through the imposition of a levy on drinking milk.

(4) The Federal Government is providing $1.78 billion in funds to assist dairy farmers and dairy dependent communities adjust to deregulation. Consumers are ultimate beneficiaries of market milk deregulation. These funds are being raised through the imposition of the 11 cent levy over about 8 years on liquid milk products.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) As part of the GST compensation package, has the Government agreed to provide primary schools with a grant of $28m to enable them to purchase Australian books for their libraries.

(2) Does the $28m equate to approximately $2.50 additional funding per student per year, totalling $10 per student over four years; if not, does the grant equal $0.635 additional funding per student per year, totalling $2.50 per student over four years.
(3) Will the grants be made available to primary schools in March or April 2001; if not, (a) why not and (b) when will schools be able to access these grants.
(4) How will the State Governments administer the correct payment to each school.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Grants to Primary School Libraries Programme is a Commonwealth initiative that forms part of the Book Industry Assistance Plan. The programme's objective is to provide financial assistance to libraries of Australian primary schools in connection with the acquisition of books of Australian authors or books produced in Australia. The Commonwealth allocation for this programme is $27.4m over four years.

(2) The $28m equates to an estimated additional 1,866,600 books or associated resources to be purchased by primary school libraries over the next four years. This assumes an average cost of $15 per book or resource.

(3) The contracts between the Commonwealth and the State Governments, Independent School Associations and Catholic Education Commissions have been sent out and funding will be provided by the Commonwealth on receipt of the signed contracts. It is up to the individual authorities as to when the funding will be distributed to individual schools.

(4) The method of administration and delivery of funds is a matter for the individual State bodies to decide. The contract states, however, that they must ensure that primary schools with less than 20 primary students receive $50 and that the remaining funds must be distributed to the remaining schools based on an equal amount per student.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) When does the term of Michael Baume, Australian Consul-General in New York, expire.
(2) How many offices and official residences has Mr Baume used during his term.
(3) What were the addresses of the (a) offices and (b) official residences.

(4) Were any (a) renovations, (b) restorations, (c) improvements, (d) additions, (e) relocations and (f) repairs made to, or carried out on, the (i) buildings, (ii) grounds, (iii) furniture and (iv) fittings at any of the offices or official residence of the Consul-General during the term of Mr Baume.

(5) What was cost of each (a) renovation, (b) restoration, (c) improvement, (d) addition, (e) relocation and (f) repair made to the offices and official residence of the Consul-General during the term of Mr Baume.
(6) What were the names of the (a) tradesperson or companies which carried out the work referred to in part (4) and (b) persons or companies from whom additions and new furniture were purchased.

(7) What was the total sum of Commonwealth funds used for (a) renovations, (b) restorations, (c) improvements, (d) additions, (e) relocations and (f) repairs to the buildings, grounds, furniture and fittings of the Consular-Generals office and official residences during the term of Mr Baume.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) This year (2001).
(2) Three offices and one residence.
(1) (a) Rockefeller Plaza, 630 Fifth Avenue, New York from October 1996 until December 1997. 1 Liberty Plaza, New York, from January to March 1998. 150 East 42 Street, New York from April 1998.
(b) Apartment 5/6C, 1 Beekman Place, New York.

(2) (i) (a, b, c, d and f) New offices, including the Consul-General's office, were fitted out for the Consulate-General and Australia's mission to the United Nations at 150 East 42nd Street, New York.

Minor or routine renovations and repairs have been carried out at the official residence including touch up painting in bathrooms, servicing and repair of major appliances (including air conditioning), replacement of broken window glass and normal plumbing repairs.

(e) The Consulate-General and Mission to the United Nations relocated (at a considerable rental saving) from their former separate premises to their new co-located offices in 1998. The Consulate-General spent a brief period in rent free transit offices between the time it vacated its old Rockefeller Plaza offices and the move into its new offices at 42nd Street.
(ii) (a, b, c, d, e and f)The offices of the Consulate-General do not have, nor have had, any grounds attached to them.
The small shared grounds of the official residence are maintained from co-operative funds.
(iii and iv) New furniture and fittings were provided in the offices of the Consulate-General and Mission to the United Nations at 42nd Street as part of the relocation.
One sofa was recovered, and a replacement industrial refrigerator/freezer purchased for the official residence.

(3) (a, b, c, d, e, f) AUD 87,144 was spent on the relocation of the Consulate-General to its new premises at 42nd St (which includes the move into and out of the interim offices at Liberty Plaza). Fit out of offices for the Consulate-General and the Mission to the United Nations at 42nd St, including window and floor treatments, and furniture was AUD 3.16 million.
Official residence minor repairs and maintenance was AUD 21,760, new sofa covering was AUD 4,952 and replacement refrigerator/freeze was AUD 7,710.

(6) (a) The fit out of offices at 42nd St was carried out by LEHR Construction Co. Relocation of offices from Rockefeller Plaza via Liberty Plaza to 42nd St was carried out by Central Moving and Storage Co. Inc.

At the official residence: servicing of the air-conditioning units was carried out by ABCO Mechanical Corp; painting by Gotham Painting Co; window glass replaced by Manhattan Shade and Glass Co; servicing of major appliances by Manhattan Gas and Electric Co.; plumbing services by Glashower Co; fire extinguishers serviced by Fire Extinguishers Co; sofa recovered by Kandp Upholstery Co.

(b) Furniture for the new offices at 42nd Street was purchased from Sterling Interior Group and Design Craft in Australia. The refrigerator/freezer for the official residence was purchased from Krups Kitchen and Bath Co.

(7) The total cost of a, b, c, d and f, for the Consulate-General is unable to be separated from the combined costs for the Consulate-General and the Mission to the United Nations. As stated above, the total cost of fit out, including window and floor treatments, and furniture for the Consulate-General and the Mission to the United Nations was AUD 3.16 million.
In relation to the official residence, Commonwealth funds expended total AUD 34,382.
(e)As stated above the cost of relocating the Consulate-General offices from Rockefeller Plaza via Liberty Plaza to 42nd St was AUD 87,144.

subdebateinfo.title: Prospect Electorate: Work for the Dole Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2462)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 26 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) How many people participated in the Work for the Dole projects in the electoral division of Prospect in (a) 1996, (b) 1997,(c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000 and (f) 2001.
(2) Will he give the locations of each of these projects and a description of the work involved.
(3) What organisations were contracted to provide Work for the Dole programs in the electoral division of Prospect.
(4) Does he plan to increase Work for the Dole programs; if so, how many new programs will be located in the electoral division of Prospect.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Work for the Dole programme was not in operation in 1996. The number of people who commenced in Work for the Dole activities in the electorate of Prospect are as follows.
*Based on start date of the activity, some people may have commenced in the following year where activities span more than one calendar year.
**As at 30 March 2001

(2) The attached table sets out the locations and description of the projects in the electorate of Prospect. The allocation of business to Community Work Coordinators (CWCs) (and sponsors in previous rounds of the programme), is based around Employment Service Areas (ESAs). CWCs are required to make available Work for the Dole places for eligible job seekers resident in the ESA for which the CWC is contracted. ESA boundaries do not coincide with federal electorate boundaries.

Therefore in the case of the federal electorate of Prospect, whilst these projects/activities may be located in the Prospect electorate, and some participants would reside in the Prospect electorate, participants may have been drawn from parts of the ESA/s that are located in neighbouring federal electorates. Furthermore, projects/activities located in other parts of the ESA/s that fall into neighbouring federal electorates may recruit participants living in the Prospect electorate.
(3) The attached table sets out the organisations that were contracted to provide Work for the Dole programme projects in the electoral division of Prospect.
(4) Decisions of the future of the programme will be considered in the context of the Budget.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business: Employee Entitlements Support Scheme
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2463)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 26 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) How many applications were received by his Department for access to the Employee Entitlements Support Scheme (EESS) in 2000.
(2) How many applications were (a) approved and (b) rejected.
(3) What sum of Commonwealth funds was paid out through the EESS in 2000.
(4) What was the (a) largest and (b) smallest sum paid out through the EESS in 2000.
(5) How many times was the maximum entitlement paid to a claimant.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Department received 3391 applications in relation to the Employee Entitlements Support Scheme (EESS) in 2000.

(2) 1493 applications were approved during 2000 and a further 127 applicants were determined to be ineligible. The remaining 1771 applications received in 2000 have been, or are being processed in 2001.
(3) $3,176,073 of Commonwealth funds was paid out through the EESS in 2000.

(4) The largest sum paid out through the EESS in 2000 was $9900.42 and the smallest sum was $14.27. These amounts would have been doubled if the States or the Australian Capital Territory had contributed to the Scheme. (No claimants from the Northern Territory, the only state or territory contributor, were paid in 2000.)

(5) The maximum entitlement ($20,000 if the Commonwealth and the relevant state or territory contribute, or $10,000 if the Commonwealth only contributes) has not been paid to any claimant since the inception of the Scheme. However, some claimants would have received 100 per cent of what they were owed for components covered by the Scheme if the relevant state of territory had contributed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 27 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has he or his Department considered repealing s.17 of the Australian Citizenship Act to allow dual citizenship to Australian born persons; if not, why not.
(2) How many overseas born dual citizens live in Australia.
(3) Is the Government considering the dual citizenship issue.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Citizenship Council, an independent advisory body which I appointed in August 1998 to provide advice on citizenship matters, recommended in their report released in February 2000 that s17 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 be repealed.
I expect that the Government response to the report of the Australian Citizenship Council will be released shortly.
(2) An estimated 4.4 million Australian citizens hold another citizenship. Most of these are Australian citizens born overseas and their Australian-born children.
(3) The Government is considering issues surrounding the repeal of s17 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 in the context of its response to the report of the Australian Citizenship Council.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is there a Jobs Pathway Program service provider operating within the electoral division of Prospect; if not, why not; if so, what is the name and the address of the Job Pathway Program service provider.
(2) How many people living in the electoral division of Prospect have found employment through the Jobs Pathway Program.
(3) How many (a) full time, (b) part time and (c) casual positions has the Job Pathway Program filled in the electoral division of Prospect.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) There are two Jobs Pathway Programme (JPP) service providers operating with the NSW electorate of Prospect. These are:
Penrith Skills for Jobs Ltd trading as Jobquest
Suite 101, 114-116 Henry Street
PENRITH NSW 2750
Australian Sports Industry Group Training Company Ltd
14 Fennell Street
NORTH PARRAMATTA NSW 2151

(2) The JPP is not an employment programme. Rather, the programme focuses on providing transitional assistance to young people who have recently left school or are thinking of leaving school in the following 12 months. The objective of JPP is to assist young people make a successful transition from school to work, further education or training through the provision of assistance that focuses on the skills and knowledge required to reduce the risk of their falling through the cracks and becoming unemployed.
(3) The JPP is not an employment programme.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) On what date did the Government receive the final report of the Review of the Australian Services Cadet Scheme entitled Cadets: The Future.
(2) On what date was the report released to the public.
(3) Of the 48 recommendations contained in the report, which have been (a) adopted by the Government, (b) rejected by the Government and (c) deferred for further consideration.
(4) What changes, if any, has the Government made to the management arrangements for the Services Cadet Scheme since the release of the report.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) 8 December 2000.
(3) (a), (b) and (c) The Department of Defence is currently formulating a plan for the progressive implementation of the report recommendations, which is to be considered by the Government.

(4) On 1 April 2001, Major General D.C. Low Choy AM, MBE, RFD, was appointed to the new position of Director-General of Cadets. A Directorate of Defence Force Cadets is being established to bring together the management of the three Service cadet elements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Does the Defence Whistleblower Scheme, as detailed in Circular Memorandum 48/97 of 24 July 1997, have a statutory basis; if so, under what legislation or regulations does the scheme operate.
(2) If the scheme does not have a statutory basis, what are the implications of this for potential whistleblowers.

(3) Are complaints of wrongdoing under the scheme to be disclosed only to staff of the Fraud Investigation and Recovery Directorate on a need to know basis; if so, what redress is available to whistleblowers if the content of their complaint is disclosed to others without their consent.

(4) Are whistleblowers to be given organisational protection against harassment or career threatening retaliatory action; if so, who within Defence is responsible for providing such protection and what redress is available to whistleblowers who subsequently experience harassment and retaliatory action.
(5) Does the Inspector-General's unit maintain statistics on the number of allegations of wrongdoing received under the scheme; if so, how many such allegations have been recorded since July 1997.

(6) As a result of allegations of wrongdoing received under the Scheme, how many individuals have been successfully prosecuted for offences under (a) the Crimes Act 1914, (b) the Public Service Act 1922 or (c) the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) It is an administrative scheme. The Department of Defence is presently developing a whistleblower scheme that meets the statutory obligations under Section 16 of the Public Service Act 1999 and Division 2.2 of the Public Service Regulations.

(2) The scheme is administrative in nature and therefore most actions taken under the scheme are administrative. However, where it can be proven that breaches of the Crimes Act 1914, the Public Service Act 1999 or the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 have occurred, then action under the relevant legislation is normally taken.

(3) Under the Defence Whistleblower Scheme, no assurances are given to whistleblowers that the allegations they make will not be disclosed in the course of investigation. Indeed, if allegations against an individual appear to have some foundation then natural justice requires that the individual concerned be given the opportunity to respond to the allegations.

(4) Any member of Defence, whether a whistleblower or not, should be protected from harassment, victimisation, discrimination or retaliation. Where an individual signals that this may occur, then it is the responsibility of the Group Manager to take avoiding or remedial action. If a member of Defence was subject to harassment, victimisation, discrimination or retaliation, then it is expected that the matter would be referred for investigation with a view to disciplinary action being taken against the individuals concerned.
(5) Records indicate that the Inspector-General Division has received allegations from 16 whistleblowers since 1 July 1997.

(6) As a result of the allegations made by the 16 whistleblowers since 1 July 1997, one person has been prosecuted under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and consideration is presently being given as to whether changes should be brought against a second person. Three further cases are currently still under investigation.

quote.para: (1) Following the introduction of the Optional Rent Assistance (ORA) scheme in May 2000, how many Defence personnel without dependants in each State and Territory are currently receiving ORA to live off base.
(2) What was the cost to the Budget of the ORA scheme in 1999-2000 and what is the projected cost for 2000-2001.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
