subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs: Employer Awareness Kit
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2480)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 28 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Did he, on 9 March 2001, in a press release entitled Unlawful Workers Picked Up on Building Sites in Sydney, promise the CMFEU a copy of his Department's Employer Awareness Kit; if so, has a copy of the kit been made available to the Union; if not, when will the kit be delivered.
(2) Are copies of the kit automatically sent to employers in industries that traditionally have a high incidence of using illegal workers, or are they available only on request.
(3) Will he provide a copy of the kit to my office.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I issued the media release referred to on 9 March 2001 and my Department sent copies of the Employer Awareness kit to the CFMEU office in Sydney on that same day.

(2) In May 1999, when the current kit and pamphlet Employing Overseas Workers - doing the right thing were released, copies were distributed to all Members of Parliament and Senators and to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) regional offices for distribution to employers and organisations through DIMA Business Centres and by compliance officers undertaking employer awareness visits, information sessions and compliance operations. Copies were also provided to individuals and organisations that requested them. In addition, approximately 4,500 kits and 41,000 pamphlets were mailed out by the Department to employers in the primary, mining and hospitality industries. The kit is also available on the DIMA Internet homepage. A new edition of the kit is in preparation and will receive similar broad distribution.
(3) Yes. That has been done.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 28 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) How many subclass 457 visas have been issued since 1 October 2000.
(2) What is the (a) industry and (b) occupational profile of subclass 457 visas issued since 1 October 2000.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) From 1 October to 31 March 2001 there have been 18,149 subclass 457 visas granted in Australia and overseas - including 1,530 visa grants to Independent Executives (people who come to Australia to establish a business with their own capital).

(2) Latest statistics on the industry data will not be available until later in the year. The table provided below shows the industry profile of all Business (long stay) subclass 457 nominations lodged in 1998/99. The occupation data table shows the occupations of all Business (long stay) subclass 457 visas granted to primary applicants overseas from 1 October 2000 to 31 March 2001.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 28 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Are visitors who enter Australia on an Electronic Travel Authority given any physical evidence of the date of issue of the visa, or the date by which they would need to leave Australia to comply with the conditions of that visa.

(2) Is a record kept of the number of visitors who have entered Australia on an Electronic Travel Authority and have stayed beyond the terms of that visa claiming to be unaware of the expiry date; if so, how many visitors fell into this category so far this intake year.
(3) Does his Department automatically impose a penalty on visitors who have overstayed on Electronic Travel Authorities; if not, in what circumstances will his Department demonstrate leniency.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) is an electronic approval for travel and entry to Australia, which replaces the visa label in the passport and removes the need for application forms. All ETAs authorise stays of 3 months upon arrival.

While no physical evidence of an ETA is provided, extensive training of ETA service providers is undertaken to ensure applicants are aware of the conditions of the ETA visas. ETA service providers receive training and literature from my Department, which emphasises that ETAs provide short-term entry to Australia, and are supported by a global network of ETA Liaison Officers stationed in key Immigration offices overseas. Ongoing training by these offices emphasises the need for ETA service providers to make clients aware of the validity and conditions of their ETA or have access to this information. Information leaflets have been widely distributed.

All passengers, other than Australian citizens, receive a port and date stamp in their passport as they are processed through the entry and departure control points. For all visa holders, including ETA holders, the arrival stamp represents the commencement of the authorised period of stay.

(2) My Department does collect statistics on the number of people who arrive in Australia and do not comply with the departure conditions of the visa on which they entered or any subsequent visa, but not their reasons for failing to depart on time. The current statistics show that some 7151 (0.33%) ETA holders, of which 2,141,779 were lawfully in Australia in the period 01 July 2000 to 31 March 2001, have overstayed.

(3) Provisions under the Migration Act 1958 and Migration Regulations impose a three-year exclusion period for anyone overstaying their visa by more than 28 days. There is provision for the three year exclusion to be waived in circumstances where there are compassionate or compelling circumstances that would affect the interests of Australia or an Australian citizen, Australian resident or an eligible New Zealand citizen.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 28 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is it intended that the minimum support contribution of $260 p.a. required under s.66 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 shall apply in the case of a non-custodial parent who is unemployed, but who is excluded from Centrelink payments due to income or asset testing of a different partner ?
(2) Is it intended that a non-custodial parent who has no income, be required to pay the minium amount provided under the Act ?
(3) Is there scope to apply for exemption under the administration powers delegated to this legislation ?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) It would only apply if the non-resident parent had their own income of at least $260 per annum.
(2) A non resident parent who has no income can apply to the Child Support Registrar for the amount payable to be reduced to nil.

(3) Section 66A of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 allows for an application to be made to the Child Support Registrar to reduce the amount to nil if the non-resident parent's income is less than $260 per annum.

subdebateinfo.title: Sustainable Energy Development Authority: Green Power Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2485)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 28 March 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether (a) in 2000, the Sustainable Energy Development Authority (SEDA) won the Prime Minister's Environment Award for Innovation and Excellence, in recognition of its `Green Power' program's achievements in addressing greenhouse gas emissions through renewable and alternative energy initiatives, carbon sequestration, pollution abatement and public education about global warming and (b) the voluntary green power component in electricity accounts is subject to the GST.

(2) If so, (a) is it contradictory policy for the Government to be awarding SEDA for its efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions whilst simultaneously deterring people from joining green power initiatives by taxing them and (b) will the Government, in the interest of encouraging involvement in such environmental schemes, consider making such supplies GST free; if not, why not.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr Truss
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) The Sustainable Energy Development Authority of New South Wales was awarded the Prime Minister's environment Award for Innovation and Excellence on World Environment Day on 5 June 2000. This award was made in recognition of its achievements in its Green Power Program in curtailing greenhouse gas emissions through a number of initiatives.
(b) The voluntary green power component of domestic electricity accounts is subject to GST as it applies to the total cost of electricity consumed by the householder.

(2) (a) While it is in the Government's purview to grant awards in recognition of environmental excellence, the Government has no management control over green power programs as these are implemented by States. The Government recognises the significant contribution made by Australians who subscribe to green power programs. Accordingly, the Government made an additional contribution of $26 million to the Renewable Energy Commercialisation Program as compensation for GST on green power programs. The Government also introduced the Photovoltaic Rebate Program to provide incentives for home owners and community organisations to install photovoltaic systems to generate electricity for domestic use. At approximately 50 percent of the capital cost of photovoltaic panels, this more than offsets the cost of the ten percent GST on photovoltaic equipment.

(b) The Government does not intend to remove GST from the green power component of domestic electricity charges. The Government believes that through its reform of the taxation system it has been able to substantially increase the public investment in sustainable energy.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 29 March 2001:

quote.para: On most recent data, how many veteran pension recipients reside in the electoral division of Chisholm and the postcode areas of (a) 3128, (b) 3129, (c) 3125, (d) 3127, (e) 3149, (f) 3148, (g) 3147, (h) 3150, (i) 3168, (j) 3166, (k) 3169 and (l) 3151.

Mr Bruce Scott

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Some persons may receive more than one Veterans' Affairs pension. For this reason the total number of pensioners will not match the sum of the different pension types.
The table below illustrates the number of pension recipients residing in the following nominated postcode areas as at 14 April 2001:

Many of the above postcode districts do not lie exclusively in the electorate of Chisholm. For this reason the total number of pension recipients in these postcodes do not match the total in the electoral division of Chisholm.
* This figure has been derived by matching postcodes to electoral boundaries to determine pensioner numbers by using a predetermined postcode/electoral boundary formula.

Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (3) Yes. Commonwealth funding to the Federation is based on acceptable outcomes against an agreed Work Plan. See also answer to part (5) below.
(4) Four - two full-time and two part-time.

(5) There is some concern about the Federation's ability to deliver fully representative advice to the government. However, the recently elected Chair of the Federation has a formal plan in place to address the perceived problems that have led to the suspensions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 2 April 2001:

talk.start.para: asked the Acting Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 3 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) What are the guidelines governing the sale of Essendon Airport.
(2) Are there any restrictions on providing information to interested parties about the process of sale; if so, (a) what are the restrictions and (b) who determined them.
(3) Are there any confidentially requirements placed on potential buyers; if so, what are the requirements.
(4) Who determined the confidentiality requirements and are they standard.
(5) Have the confidentiality requirements been used in any other airport sale.

(6) Have any agencies or third parties been appointed to assist in the sale; if so, (a) what are the reporting requirements of such agencies or parties and (b) are they required to report to Parliament; if so, when.
(7) What is the timetable for the sale.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The guidelines governing the sale of Essendon Airport Limited are consistent with previous airport sales. In particular, the guidelines provide for:
- the continued operation of the airport as a general aviation airport;
- the price offered within the context of the other objectives;
- managerial and financial strength of the new Essendon Airport operator; and
- fair and equitable treatment of employees of EAL.
(2) Yes.
(a) In line with standard processes, interested parties are provided with information about the process of the sale on entering into a confidentiality agreement.
(b) The Office of Asset Sales and IT Outsourcing (OASITO) based on legal advice and in accordance with standard commercial practice.
(3) Yes. All potential buyers are required to enter into formal confidentiality agreements with the Commonwealth.
(4) OASITO, based on legal advice, determines the confidentiality requirements. These arrangements are consistent with standard commercial practice and previous sale processes.
(5) Yes.
(6) Yes.
(a) Advisers appointed to the sale are required to report to OASITO.
(b) No. OASITO continues to be accountable to the Parliament.
(7) The sale process is expected to be completed by around mid 2001.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is 501 Wing RAAF Base Amberley being moved to RAAF Base Williamtown; if so, what are the details of timings and personnel changes involved at RAAF Base Amberley.
(2) Is there a proposal to reduce the number of Air Commodores at RAAF Base Amberley from two to one.
(3) What is the reason for the change in RAAF Base Amberley commanding officer structure.

(4) What effect will a change in commanding officer structure at RAAF Base Amberley have on the operations of the base and its ability to liaise with the community and provide a public face to the operations of the base.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. However, deeper maintenance for F111 aircraft, which is undertaken by 501 Wing, has been a long planned market testing exercise. Outsourcing has its origin with the Force Structure Review and the rolling Commercial Support Program, which commenced in the early 1990s. Final implementation and transition of 501 Wing deeper maintenance to contractor support has undergone several delays but is expected to be completed by the end of 2001.

(2) Yes. A study, which is reviewing the options for the amalgamation of Tactical Fighter Group and Strike Reconnaissance Group into a single Air Combat Group (ACG), is currently underway. It is most likely that the ACG headquarters would be located at RAAF Williamtown and would result in a reduction in the number of Air Commodores at RAAF Amberley. The study will present its findings later this year with a planned implementation of early 2002.

(3) The creation of ACG would enable a more effective air combat (strike/fighter) capability to be achieved and other operational, support and logistics synergies to be realised. This will be particularly important for the new air combat capability to be delivered under Project AIR6000. As detailed in the White Paper, AIR6000 seeks to examine options for acquiring new combat aircraft to replace the F/A-18 and F-111. Although there is considerable effort required to refine the AIR6000 options, including whether a single aircraft type can meet both the strike and fighter roles, a solution which provides for both strike an fighter roles could result in increased combat effectiveness and significant savings. The formation of ACG will allow a range of options to be explored and doctrine to be established. This should ensure a seamless transition to the capability to be delivered by AIR6000.

(4) Minimal impact to the base operations and community liaison is expected as a consequence of the proposed ACG reorganisation. RAAF Amberley base operations will not change under the ACG proposal. RAAF Amberley currently has two Air Commodores in residence, Commander Strike Reconnaissance Group (CDRSRG) and Commander Combat Support Group (CDRCSG). Headquarters Combat Support Group relocated to RAAF Amberley in 1999, raising the number of Air Commodores from one to two. Since that time, regional liaison responsibility has become a shared responsibility between CDRSRG and CDRCSG. CDRCSG's community liaison responsibilities are expected to be similar in scope to those of CDRSRG, prior to 1999.

subdebateinfo.title: Defence: Airborne Early Warning and Control
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2502)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) Prior to Government decisions based on the recent Defence White Paper, did Project Wedgetail Airborne Early Warning and Control (AEW&C) involve an agreement and understanding that Australia would purchase 7 Boeing 737s, 2 of which were to be assembled in Seattle, USA, as prototypes and the remaining 5 aircraft were to be assembled in Australia, in particular at RAAF Base Amberley.

(2) Can he confirm the exact number and timing of the Boeing 737s to be assembled, the place of assembly and scope for change to any contractual agreement with Boeing in relation to the AEW&C project.

(3) What commitment can he give in relation to his statement in letters to the editor of the Queensland Times on Saturday, 24 March 2001 that the number of aircraft can be varied and that no decision has to be made up to and including 2003.
(4) If he is committed to the possibility of increasing the number of aircraft from 4 at present to any other number in the future, can he give details of the actual number and timing of delivery.
(5) Are there contractual arrangements with Boeing to accommodate the assembly of AEW&C 737's in Australia should the Government decide to purchase 7 aircraft as originally indicated.

(6) Is he aware of the impact reducing the number of AEW&C 737's purchased by Australia will have on the Australian Defence Industry; if so, how will he compensate the Australian Defence Industry for the loss of potential technology and employment development.
(7) Will the downsizing of Project Wedgetail from 7 AEW&C aircraft reduce the capacity of the AEW&C system as a recognised defence strategy of Australia's national security.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Prior to consideration in the context of the Defence 2000 White Paper, the Commonwealth issued in September 1998 a Request for Tender for the acquisition of six or seven AEW&C aircraft; the actual number being dependant on the overall cost remaining within approved Project funding. Based on tendered cost information, the Defence Capability Committee in March 2000 recommended the acquisition of six aircraft with an option for a seventh.

There was never an agreement with Boeing to assemble 737 aircraft in Australia, nor any intention to have such an agreement. The intention was always to have all the 737 aircraft assembled on Boeing's 737 production line at their facility at Renton, Washington, USA.

Boeing had, however, planned to install the AEW&C equipment into the first two of these 737 aircraft in the United States as prototypes, with the remaining aircraft having the equipment installed in Australia. The actual location at which these modifications were to be carried out was a commercial decision for Boeing; however, it was understood and expected this work would be done in a commercial facility at RAAF Base Amberley.

(2) As stated earlier, all 737 aircraft will be assembled at the Boeing facility at Renton, Washington, USA as originally planned. However, with an order of only four aircraft, increased risk, schedule and overall cost related to transitioning the modification activities to Australia for only two aircraft was considered prohibitive, making it more prudent for all four aircraft to be completed in the United States.
It is currently planned that Wedgetail 737 aircraft A30-01 will be assembled in April/May 2003; A30-02 in November/December 2004; A30-03 in August/September 2005 and A30-04 in April/May 2006.

Where installation and checkout of mission system equipment will now occur is a commercial decision for Boeing, however, it is understood it will be carried out at the Boeing facility in Wichita, Kansas, USA.

Should Australia purchase the additional AEW&C aircraft, there is scope for the Government to negotiate to have installation and checkout of the complex AEW&C mission systems in Australia at a location to be decided by Boeing, but most likely in a commercial facility at RAAF Base Amberley.
(3) The Defence 2000 White Paper states the possibility of acquiring a further three AEW&C aircraft later in the decade.
There is an option in the Commonwealth's contract with Boeing that will allow the purchase of these additional aircraft at the originally negotiated price until early 2003.
After early 2003, additional AEW&C aircraft can still be purchased, but at a price to be negotiated based on the commercial price at the time.
(4) The Defence 2000 White Paper states the possibility of acquiring a further three AEW&C aircraft later in the decade. That decision will be taken at the appropriate time.

(5) There has never been a contractual arrangement to accommodate the assembly of 737 AEW&C aircraft in Australia. However, should the additional three AEW&C aircraft be acquired, there is scope within the contract to negotiate the installation and checkout of complex AEW&C mission systems in Australia at a location to be decided by Boeing, but most likely in a commercial facility at RAAF Base Amberley.

(6) AEW&C Australian industry involvement has always focused on the important areas of technology, through life support and the associated jobs created over the 30 year life of the AEW&C aircraft rather than limited short term objectives. Installation of the AEW&C equipment into only two aircraft in Australia would not have added significantly to achievement of our goals for long-term in-country support.

Work amounting to about $400 million will still be undertaken by Australian industry including the design and development of some radar, electronic warfare, communications and mission system elements.

A Strategic Industry Development Activity program with a value in the order of $880 million is also in place and includes high technology activities such as training, skills transfer, collaborative ventures and research and development projects.

(7) No. AEW&C aircraft are a very important part of Australia's Defence Strategy. The minimum number of AEW&C aircraft required to establish an effective capability is four, so this is the number the Government has initially ordered as part of the balanced force designed to achieve our National Security goal. The Defence 2000 White Paper also recognises that additional AEW&C aircraft would provide significant advantages provided that they are affordable when the remainder of our investment needs are considered. It is for this reason that the White Paper states the possibility of acquiring a further three aircraft later in the decade.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 3 April 2001:

quote.para: Have any buildings owned by the Australian Customs Service (ACS) been sold during 2000-2001; if so, will the Minister provide details of (a) the location of any buildings which have been sold, (b) any valuations of market value which were obtained prior to sale, (c) the sale price and (d) if the property was subsequently leased back by the ACS, the details of the subsequent lease agreement.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Australian Customs Service (Customs) has not sold any commercial buildings during 2000-2001.

During 2000-2001 Customs sold a residence at 12 Ryan Close, Brinsmead, Cairns, Queensland. The property was valued between $137,500 and $145,000 and was sold for $138,500. The property was not leased back by Customs.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) Is it a fact that (a) Telstra BigPond Internet access in Newcastle is priced at a higher rate than Sydney and (b) monthly-unlimited access costs $42.50 in Newcastle and $24.95 in Sydney.
(2) Why does this price differential exist.
(3) When will this impost on the Newcastle community end.
(4) Does Telstra charge all regional Internet users in the same way.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) and (b) Telstra advises the answer to the question is no. Telstra advises that the price of accessing Telstra BigPond in Newcastle is the same price as access in Sydney. There is no $42.50 unlimited Internet access plan provided by Telstra BigPond.
(2) As the answer to question 1 is no, there can be no answer to question 2.
(3) There is no additional impost on the Newcastle community in relation to Telstra's prices for access to the Internet.
(4) Telstra advises that it charges regional Internet customers in the same way as capital city Internet customers.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business: Derogatory Comments
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2518)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 5 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Bulletin on 3 April 2001 alleging that a derogatory reference to Indonesia had been made by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business.
(2) Has he discussed this matter with the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business.
(3) Have there been any references in the Indonesian media to the comments made by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business; if so, what were these references.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: I regard the questions as frivolous.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 5 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) What communication facilities are made available to asylum seekers who have entered Australia without authorisation, while they are detained in immigration processing centres.
(2) Are detainees in Australia's immigration processing centres permitted access to communication facilities; if not, what limits are placed on such access.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Telephones, fax machines, postal services, newspapers, televisions (cable and/or free to air), radios and video cassette recorders are available to unauthorised arrivals accommodated in Australia's immigration detention facilities.

(2) All detainees in Australia's immigration detention facilities have access to the communication facilities I have just mentioned. However, some general access rules apply depending on whether the detainee is accommodated within the general population or is accommodated in separation detention as follows:

answer.para: Â· Telephone - user pay telephones for incoming and outgoing calls are available in each of the detention facilities. Depending on the location of the public telephone in the centre, access maybe restricted to prescribed hours, unless extenuating circumstances apply.
Â· Fax machines - use is restricted to urgent immigration processing and related matters.
Â· Television - no restriction.
Â· Videos - no X-rated or R-rated material is made available for viewing, this can also extend to the M-rated classification.
Â· Mail - unsolicited mail will be returned to the sender. No restriction on the sending and receiving of private mail.
Â· Newspapers - no restriction to access newspapers subscribed to by the relevant detention centre.
Â· Radio broadcasts - no restriction.

quote.para: All new arrivals at Immigration Reception and Processing Centres (IRPCs) - ie. Woomera, Port Hedland and Curtin - are placed in accommodation that is separate from the established detention population. This is known as separation detention. This is maintained throughout initial entry screening, health checking and establishment of identity. During the period of separation detention, access to communication facilities such as newspapers, radio or general television broadcasts is limited.

Upon initial arrival at the centre, detainees are permitted to send a message to friends/relatives overseas to advise of their safe arrival and an address to which correspondence can be sent. They can receive correspondence from family overseas. Unsolicited mail is returned to the sender.

In addition, if a detainee asks for a lawyer or for assistance to make an application for a visa, communication facilities are made available, through the on-site Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs office to contact appropriate service providers.
During the period of separation detention access to videos is permitted. Classification restrictions apply as per the general detention population.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 5 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) How many employers have been issued with warnings by his Department since the introduction of the new warning scheme for employers found to be using illegal labour.
(2) What is the industry profile of employers that have received warnings for employing Illegal Workers under the new scheme.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As at 6 April 2001, 20 employers had received Illegal Worker Warning Notices under the administrative warning notice regime that was introduced on 30 November 2000. A warning notice relates to an individual worker, and a total of 34 warning notices had been issued to these 20 employers as a result of their employing Illegal Workers.
It should be noted that warning notices can only be issued to employers or labour suppliers where the illegal worker commenced work after 30 November 2000.
(2) Table A below identifies the number of employers who received warning notices and the number of warning notices issued by industry.
TABLE A
ILLEGAL WORKER WARNING NOTICES ISSUED AS AT 6 APRIL 2001
Note: Industry classifications accord with the Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC) codes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 5 April 2001:

quote.para: (1) When will he adopt the `Swedish Model' approach to detention of asylum seekers in Australia.
(2) How many asylum seekers will be offered this option.
(3) What will be the process of evaluation of potential recipients of this option.
(4) What conditions will be offered to these recipients.
(5) If not all available places are filled, will he offer the available positions to other asylum seekers.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister for Reconciliation and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I have studied the concept of the Swedish Model and I do not believe that it applies to our circumstances. I am considering a trial of alternative detention arrangements that may have elements of the Swedish Model; however, I am not considering the Swedish approach to immigration detention in total.
(2) It is planned that up to 25 women and children will participate in the trial.

(3) This issue is among those still being worked out by my Department. However, the proposed trial will only be open to women and children and will be approximately three months in length. Whether it will be a permanent arrangement will be determined by an evaluation of the trial, after that time.

(4) Subject to satisfactory arrangements being agreed with the Woomera community, the participants will be located in community housing within Woomera town but under immigration detention. This is a trial of alternative detention arrangements not a release into the community.
Consultations continue with Woomera residents on this and other issues.
(5) All places in the trial will be filled on a voluntary basis. At this stage it is difficult to predict the response from the detainee population with regard to participation rates.
